DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF SIR FRANK MACFARLANE BURNET

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House expresses its deep regret at the death on 31 August 1985 of Sir Frank Macfarlane Burnet, places on record its recognition and esteem for his meritorious public service and unique contribution to medical science and tenders its profound sympathy to Sir Macfarlane's widow and family.

In this House, we customarily offer condolences following the death of parliamentary colleagues and friends formerly of this House. It is un- usual-we have only rarely done so-to move motions of condolence for distinguished Australians who have not sat in this House. It is indicative of the stature of those for whom such motions are moved that the last two so honoured in this way were Sir Owen Dixon, perhaps Australia's greatest jurist, and Sir John Monash, Australia's most able soldier. It is my sad duty but also my privilege today to propose to the House a similar motion for Sir Macfarlane Burnet.

As politicians, each of us works with a vision of a future Australia in mind. We try to make that vision real by reforms, innovations, adjustments and changes. For all of us that vision means a better life for ordinary Australians. However, few, if any of us, can hope for achievements in producing a better life for ordinary Australians which could match those of Sir Macfarlane Burnet. When we talk about Sir Macfarlane, we are dealing with an Australian with a large and ambitious vision. His work has made life safer and better for generations of people in this country and right around the world. He gave his life to service-service to his profession, to his talents and to his country. That work was done quietly and with modesty, but we all know that we have been enriched by his life and his work. We are all familiar with the achievements of Sir Macfarlane's career. It was a career that was distinguished by intellectual brilliance, unswerving diligence, dedication and a determination to push out the boundaries of medicine and push forward the limits of science.

The range of Sir Macfarlane's work was daunting. He work in field after field, innovating and experimenting and improving the state of science wherever he set his mind. We remember today especially his pioneering work in the study of viruses, the production of vaccines and the investigation of diseases such as influenza, poliomyelitis and Murray River encephalitis and his research into auto-immune diseases. Sir Macfarlane's unique talents were fully recognised by his peers. His Nobel Prize, his Royal Medal from the Royal Society of London, his Presidency of the Australian Academy of Science, his knighthood, his Order of Merit and his knighthood in the Order of Australia were all due and proper recognition of his quite outstanding service. It is also proper that this House should recognise Sir Macfarlane Burnet's service to his country. Australia is fortunate indeed to have enjoyed the benefits of his research, his teaching, his guidance and his experience. Sir Macfarlane Burnet brought both pride and distinction to his endeavours and to his country.

We have lost one of our most intelligent, most thoughtful and most incisive countrymen. We cannot make up that loss but we can indicate to Sir Macfarlane Burnet's widow and family, to his colleagues and to the scientific community that we in this House respect, honour and commemorate what he did for all of us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition warmly supports the condolence motion moved by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). It is, as the Prime Minister said, very rare indeed for a condolence motion of this character to be moved. I say to the Prime Minister and to the House that the choice of a condolence motion for the late Sir Macfarlane Burnet is well and truly warranted, given the enormous and conspicuous contribution that that man made to attacking disease and to building and exemplifying the reputation of scientific and medical excellence in research on the part of Australians all around the world. The Prime Minister has itemised his contribution to medical science and research from the early 1930s to the late 1950s-a span of 30 years in which he was a leader in the science of virology, and particularly influenza research. His work first as Assistant Director and then as Director of the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research is legendary in medical research in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Born in September 1899, Sir Macfarlane attended Geelong College, where he was dux, and he won a residential scholarship to Melbourne University's Ormond College. That commenced a career probably unmatched by other Australians in the field of medical research. His reputation and respect for his integrity were world wide. He received numerous honours, including, as the Prime Minister reminded us, the Royal Society and Copley medals, and, of course, the Nobel Prize. He was a foundation fellow of the Australian Academy of Science and served as its President from 1965 to 1969, He was knighted in 1951 and was awarded the Order of Merit in 1958, and he became a Knight in the Order of Australia in 1977.

On behalf of the Opposition, I join very warmly in remembering and honouring this remarkable man's contribution to the relief of suffering amongst his fellow human beings, his contribution to medical research and the distinguished contribution that he made to the intellectual and research life of Australia. I join the Prime Minister in conveying our sympathy to Sir Macfarlane's wife, his two daughters, his son and his eight grandchildren.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the members of the National Party, I join with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) in what is an almost unique tribute by this place to one who was not within the general family of those involved in the direct world of politics. It is particularly appropriate that there should be a tribute to one who made such a notable contribution through his life to the advances of knowledge in the field in which he was so expert.

SPEECH.PARA: There is little doubt that, as a Nobel laureate and as Director of the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research, Sir Macfarlane Burnet made a tremendous contribution not only to his own field of specialist technology but also to the better understanding of mankind. Sir Macfarlane was a remarkable man in every way. I think that all Australians can not only walk a little healthier but also feel a little taller for the memory of one who contributed so much to the enhancement of the status of Australians and of Australia in the field of science.

Sir Macfarlane, at one stage of his life, had a theory that when the scientists of the world work on war, then war is inevitable. Perhaps in this place it is not inappropriate to say that if politicians worked a little harder in the cause of peace, the reverse might be true. Certainly he was a great Australian and one who made an enormous contribution not only to his own field but also to the status of this country. On behalf of the members of my Party, I extend our sympathy to his widow, his children and his grandchildren.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In paying tribute to Sir Macfarlane Burnet I pay tribute to a man whose many achievements in the world of medicine and science immortalised his name during his own lifetime. That lifetime ended 10 days ago when Sir Macfarlane died peacefully at Port Fairy, Victoria, on 31 August, after a long illness, just three days short of his eighty-sixth birthday.

SPEECH.PARA: Much has been written and spoken about this unique Australian in the past 10 days and I do not wish merely to repeat his curriculum vitae and list all the honours bestowed on him. However, I would like to place on record my appreciation of the contribution made by Sir Macfarlane to the Health and well-being of every Australian through his work in the fields of biology, immunology and virology. In doing so, I am sure I speak for every member of this House.

Sir Macfarlane Burnet was a man who gave a very great deal to the advancement of science in Australia. Through his work over more than half a century he enabled Australia to take credit for substantial contributions to the sum of world scientific and medical knowledge. One of the distressing things about the arts and the sciences-in fact, about so many fields of achievement in Australia-is the number of eminent and potentially eminent people who leave this country and do not come back. True, the scholar or the artist-in whatever field-cannot be constrained or feel constrained by national or geographic or cultural boundaries. He or she must follow his or her bent unconfined by such boundaries. Sir Macfarlane Burnet was an international figure with an international reputation, much travelled and much respected beyond Australia's boundaries. But he was devoted to Australia and gave of all his considerable talents in the service of his own country. Parochial is a term that could never be used to describe such a man, but it is of note that he was born in Victoria, educated in Victoria, worked in Victoria and, last month, died in Victoria.

To generations of Australians working in science, and particularly in medical science, Sir Macfarlane's greatness was measured in many achievements and in many areas, as befits a man with the unblinkered mind of the true scientific scholar. To the Australian public, however, he is identified primarily with the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute where he was Assistant Director from 1928 to 1944 and Director from 1944 until his retirement in 1965. It was there, within the Institute, that he pursued those wide-ranging interests which were responsible for major advances in the health of a great many Australians. His earlier work on influenza, Q fever, poliomyelitis and Australian encephalitis and his later work in immunology has been of lasting public importance. So many people in this country have reason to be eternally grateful to Sir Macfarlane, as do so many successive Federal governments to whom he gave freely of his energy and talents.

He left his mark especially on the National Health and Medical Research Council which this year will celebrate its 50th anniversary and its 100th session. Sir Macfarlane's association with the council began virtually when the council began. It will be a matter for regret by all involved that he will not be present at those anniversary celebrations.
I regret that my own personal acquaintance with him was slight, so I conclude with a fitting quotation from Sir Gustav Nossal, his successor at the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute, who knew him well:
Let us recap the unique spectrum of Sir Macfarlane's gifts: Originality, imagination, intuition, native honesty, conceptual breadth and daring and, yes, wisdom of an almost spiritual kind.
No-one who has known him will lightly apply the adjective `great' to another. No one who loves Australian science will ever forget his example.
I extend my condolences and sympathy to his family and friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be given the opportunity to speak very briefly on this motion. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has detailed the extraordinary record of one of Australia's greatest citizens. It is unusual for a non-parliamentarian to be honoured in this way, and no one in this century stands greater than Sir Macfarlane Burnet. It is not for me to detail all of those matters already referred to. The honours were there: The Senior Order of Merit in the Commonwealth, a double Knight, a Nobel prize winner-but of far more importance to Sir Macfarlane Burnet were the actual achievements which flowed through to humanity itself.

SPEECH.PARA: The quotation of the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) of Sir Gustav Nossal sums it up: it is very rare that one can refer to greatness in others when one considers the life of Sir Macfarlane Burnet. It is therefore rare that one can say with such honesty that a person's loss is incalculable.

He was an essentially shy man. His inherent modesty was perhaps missed by many because of the firmness of conviction and the clarity with which he expressed his thoughts. Those who knew him will know what I mean when I mention that, unless one was aware of the enormity of his achievement, when listening to him one would have thought that one was talking with an extraordinarily brilliant man, but never was a reference dwelt upon, let alone made, to the great achievements in his life.

I was very fortunate that he became a close friend of mine when he married Hazel Jenkin and moved to only a few doors from me in Canterbury. His widow is a great Australian who served my predecessor in the electorate of Kooyong and served me as a Liberal-not for Mac the taints of party politics but the expression of views privately and so frequently. On many occasions I spent time with them only a few doors from my home. I and perhaps a couple of others in this House are fortunate to have been able to share some rare moments with one of our greatest Australians. He lived for this nation. No great Australian of his standing can compare with the diligence with which he sought to serve Australia for no personal gain and no ventures overseas for better material reward. I am honoured to have been given the opportunity to express a few thoughts and to pass my condolences to Hazel and his family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I pay tribute to Sir Macfarlane Burnet's extraordinary contribution to world science through Australia. Our other Nobel prize- winners in the sciences-Sir Howard Florey, Sir John Eccles and Sir John Cornforth-all left Australia to achieve recognition overseas. Sir Macfarlane made a deliberate choice to stay in this country and declined a chair at Harvard as early as 1943. In his long life he achieved greater world-wide recognition than any of our citizens. He revolutionised the study of viral disease, was a pioneer of biotechnological research and made the decisive contribution to the study of immune reactions. Unlike many contemporary scientists, he rejected a narrow specialisation and took an intense interest in the social and philosophical implications of medical and scientific discoveries.

SPEECH.PARA: Sir Macfarlane has left a decisive mark on the teaching of medical science in Australia and this will be a permanent memorial. He had been for many years, in my judgment, and leaving politics aside, the greatest living Australian. Most of his working life was spent at the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research in Melbourne, where he served as Director from 1944 to 1965. He was an unabashed Australian patriot, who took great pride that his achievements took place in his native land. He made Melbourne, as his successor Sir Gustav Nossal said, `a Mecca for medical research', and apart from his own Walter and Eliza Hall Institute, his influence, ideas and drive are reflected in the other components of the `Parkville Strip'-the Florey, Murdoch and Ludwig institutes.

In 1958 he received the Order of Merit and was the first Australian so honoured. At his death, as the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) said, he was the senior member of the Order. This was followed in 1959 by the Copley Medal, the highest award of the Royal Society. In 1960 he shared the Nobel Prize for Medicine with Sir Peter Medawar for their work on acquired immunological tolerance. Burnet created the theoretical framework in a new and major area of science, while Medawar provided the experimental proof. Sir Macfarlane published more than 250 scientific papers in the areas referred to by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett).

Inspired as a child by the writings of H. G. Wells, he had a strong urge to popularise and generalise. There were some major ironies in his career. A super-specialist, who devoted his life to investigating the smallest forms of life, he rejected reductionism and always strove to find the broadest verifiable level of generalisation and ventured bravely, and sometimes mistakenly, into broad social areas in which he was untrained. He had a very shy and retiring personality but welcomed any opportunity to speak, write and celebrate the achievements of Australian science, including his own. His industry was awesome: In retirement, between the ages of 69 and 80, he wrote 13 major books. He also delivered the Australian Broadcasting Commission Boyer lectures for 1966, and wrote some important essays.

One of my most vivid recollections was a 1969 television program featuring Sir Macfarlane Burnet and Spike Milligan in dialogue. Each began from utterly different premises and knowledge. Milligan was the man of instinct, a passionate, tormented genius, close to madness, with a wild self-lacerating humour, and a brooding sense of chaos underlying human experience. Burnet saw the world through the eyes of a self-contained rationalist and experimentalist, emotionally contained, sharply focused, suspicious of the metaphysical, analytical and inquiring. They seemed an odd couple. At first Sir Mac was distinctly uneasy at having agreed to appear with Spike. However, after a few minutes, the mixture began to work and he started to laugh. Each recognised the utter integrity of the other, could see how the other's mind worked and anticipate reactions. Starting, as they did, from diametrically opposed bases, they converged in their major concerns about the world-for peace and opposition to nuclear weapons, eliminating third world poverty, the welfare of children, quality of life issues, including education and access to the arts, and the problems of drug dependence. He died just before his eighty-sixth birthday, and I express some momentary disappointment that this event passed with such slight coverage in the media, perhaps understandable at the height of the football season. His name will live in the history of world science.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As an agricultural scientist and recently as the shadow Minister for Science and as a man who met Sir Macfarlane Burnet I would like to associate myself with this motion because this special occasion serves to remind us that the man whose memory we honour today on behalf of the Australian people was a man, as we have heard, of unique and superlative achievements. As Australia adjusts its industrial culture, its economy and its national outlook to a future based on the necessity for a strong achievement in science and technology, today, in this Parliament, we record our understanding and appreciation of his achievements and give tribute to the greatest of our men of science. I think it is also fitting that we go beyond that to reflect on those qualities and characteristics which so illuminated Sir Macfarlane's life.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a paradox which grows directly out of the nature of Sir Macfarlane Burnet and his work that his great scientific reputation was unaccompanied by any zest or interest in personal publicity. He so obviously merged the culture of a great scientific curiosity, so fully sustained throughout his life, with the most fundamental of social activities-the enjoyment of a rich and satisfying family life. The activity in one dimension drew strength from and reinforced the other. As a consequence, he was a very private person. Basically, although his work placed him in the centre of the community of world science, Sir Macfarlane never ceased to be an Australian. As we have heard from the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones), he had a crucial choice to make in 1943 when he was faced with the opportunity of going to Harvard. Should he accept Harvard or stick to Australia? That was his challenging decision. As we know, he decided to turn down the Harvard offer and stay in Australia. So his decision to base his scientific efforts in Australia and not to work in the midst of a world research centre was a deliberate decision to establish Australia as a world centre for medical science. It was a courage born of quiet confidence in his own distinctive scientific genius which made that decision a triumphantly successful one.

As we have all heard, his base was the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute. He gave great lustre to that institution. He was an immensly courageous man. At the height of the controversy during the introduction of myxomatosis he and two other scientists had themselves injected with a severe strain of the myxomatosis virus to prove that it was not harmful to human beings. That bold and imaginative action restored public confidence.

He graciously gave of his time to the promotion of science in the newly independent Commonwealth countries. As a scientist he truly wished to see our nation enlarge its confidence in itself by national effort in science and technology. He saw in our national respect for such endeavour the real future for Australian progress and confidence. In his life's work and example he truly sought to make that general vision a national reality. As we reflect on Sir Macfarlane Burnet in this Parliament we should take to our hearts something of that outlook. Mr Speaker, I extend my sympathies to his widow and family at their personal loss. May their knowledge of our gratitude as a nation truly leave them certain that his 86 years were as rare a life as ever graced the twentieth century.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to associate myself with this motion and extend my sympathies to the relatives and widow of Sir Macfarlane Burnet. It is rare in the twentieth century and, indeed, in the whole history of science for there to be some scientists who are capable of providing a conceptual revolution, that is to say, who are capable of taking established ideas, turning them around and providing that vital breakthrough which is necessary if science is to advance. The advancement of science through such revolutionary breakthroughs makes scientific endeavour one of the great human endeavours. In this way Sir Macfarlane Burnet's contribution was revolutionary. He revolutionised the whole undertaking of immunology, of viruses. As has been mentioned, in so doing he also provided the foundations for the pursuit of medicine in Australia, because, rather than export his discoveries and approach other countries, Sir Macfarlane Burnet established them here in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Last week the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's radio show, The Science Show, broadcast speeches by Sir Macfarlane in which he expressed the reasons why he decided to stay in Australia and to help establish not only the Institute but also medicine and medical research as a vital feature of the scientific community of this country. The contribution he made, not only to human scientific endeavour, but also to establishing science, and medical science in particular, in this country is awesome and, obviously, the greatest such contribution to have been made in the history of Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been a number of interesting developments in the past several weeks concerning Cambodia. I believe they reflect a qualitative change in certain important respects. In that regard some of those developments are to be welcomed because they seem encouraging. However, in connection with developments in that part of the world, one must always bear in mind that progress is extraordinarily slow and that often hopes held are later found to have been dashed. I trust that is not the case in this instance.

ANSWER.PARA: The first issue I refer to is the Indo-China Ministers' communique from Phnom Penh of 15 and 16 August. That communique was qualitatively different in that it contained apparent conciliatory elements. It appeared to stress the modalities for encouraging dialogue rather than making a dogmatic stand. One rather trusts that various interested parties will be able to encourage Vietnam to continue responding politically in a way which will allow further elaboration of views being put by various interested parties affected by developments in Cambodia. Not the least of those interested parties would be Vietnam. Accordingly, that statement is being studied very closely by the Australian Government.

The more recent statement concerned the retirement of Pol Pot. He is to be replaced by Son Sen. The question is whether that change is a substantive one, or whether Pol Pot will retain a powerful manipulative authority within the Khmer Rouge; only time will establish that. He will still be influential as chairman of the Technical Office for National Defence, but one may be able to conclude with some confidence that this shift implies that the Khmer Rouge believes Pol Pot to be an obstacle to progress towards settlement of the problem in that unhappy part of the world.

I particularly applaud the Association of South East Asian Nations Foreign Ministers' proposals for proximity talks and compliment the Foreign Minister of Malaysia, Tengku Rithauddeen, for the contribution he made in the elaboration of this particular proposal. His earlier version of a somewhat modified proposition for proximity talks seemed to hold out much hope. Accordingly, the ASEAN Foreign Ministers have built upon that proposal. I have noted comments from Vietnamese authorities that they are interested in the proposal put forward by Tengku Rithauddeen and, therefore, we would encourage further refinement of that proposal.

The efforts of Indonesian Foreign Minister, Dr Mochtar, deserve special mention. He has been indefatigable in his efforts to establish some sort of productive dialogue between Vietnam and the other Indo-Chinese countries and the ASEAN countries. As a result of his persistent industry in this area it was announced recently that talks will commence between the United States and Vietnam on the very sad issue of American personnel missing in action in the Vietnam war which concluded in 1975. One rather hopes again that this is an indication of some sorts of qualitative improvements in the general political atmospherics affecting the Indo-China situation.

Finally, I stress that there is still a long way to go before anyone can be confident that the path to resolution of this problem has been set firmly; a very long way indeed. But there are qualitative changes which are very important, and in all of this I think we can be fairly satisfied that Australia has made a not unimportant contribution and looks forward to continuing to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations aware of an Australian Council of Trade Unions report that warns about the threat to entrenched union power resulting from the growth of non-unionised contract labour? Is the ACTU correct about that threat? Will the Minister assure the House that the Government will not implement recommendation 19 of the Hancock Committee of Review into Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems which entails the virtual conscription of independent contractors into the union movement?

—I am aware that there is such a report around, but I have not seen it. Therefore, I cannot comment on it. The recommendation of the Hancock Committee in relation to independent contractors, like all other recommendations, is a matter for consideration by the Government at the present time, and eventually we will make a full response to all of those recommendations.

—I draw to the attention of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations the great interest shown by the community in the Budget youth training strategy, entitled Priority One: Young Australia, some aspects of which the Minister for Trade addressed this afternoon. Can the Minister give me and the House further details of the Government's record in creating jobs and reducing unemployment, and how this record compares with that of the previous Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the fact that this Government's record of employment growth is very impressive and I can understand honourable members opposite not wanting to listen to it. We have had two years of strong economic growth and, associated with that, two years of strong employment growth, with 410,000 new jobs. I say especially to the new Leader of the Opposition that he should take particular note of the fact that in the last 12-month period for which one can make international comparisons the rate of employment growth in this country has been the highest rate of growth of any country in the Western developed world-higher even than the United States, which was the previous pacesetter. Unemployment has fallen from its peak of 10.4 per cent to 8.2 per cent. That has meant a reduction of 33,000 in the number of teenage unemployed. We have reversed the long term trend of declining employment for teenagers and have seen a growth of over 30,000 jobs for teenagers in the last two years. Of course the traineeship proposal to which the honourable member referred will help considerably to increase the number of teenage jobs. This situation compares very well with the record of the previous Government which, as honourable members will recall, created 70,000 fewer jobs in 7 1/4 years than we have created in 2 1/4 years. Under that Government unemployment rose by 370,000, from 5 1/2 per cent to 10 per cent. Teenage employment fell by over 30,000 and teenage unemployment increased by over 100,000 in their period of office, for most of which time the present Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer.

ANSWER.PARA: It is also interesting at this time to look at what happened during that particular segment of the now Opposition's period of government when the new Opposition spokesman on employment and industrial relations had responsibility for employment policy, as Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. The House will recall that he was the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs from April 1981 until May 1982. One sees over that period a record of abysmal achievement in terms of both employment outcomes and concern for the unemployed. Let me briefly remind the House of what happened. During that period employment increased at a snail's pace, by only 16,000 jobs in that 13-month period. That is about the average monthly rate of growth of employment during our period in office. Unemployment jumped by almost 75,000, or almost 20 per cent. It is also worth noting that this was a time of decentralisation of wage fixation, and during this period, now regarded as the nirvana where there was to have been decentralised wage fixing, average weekly earnings increased by 17 per cent-the highest rate for 10 years. In regard to young people in particular, during the then Minister's period of jurisdiction we saw a drop in employment of teenagers in full time jobs of 45,000. The teenage unemployment rate went from 15.9 per cent to 19 per cent.

Everyone in this House will recall that it was this Minister who demonstrated great compassion for the unemployed by announcing the abolition of the community youth support scheme in the Budget of 1981-a decision which was met with such universal rejection in the community that the Government eventually changed its mind and decided to keep that valuable program, a program which has been greatly boosted by this Government. The attitude of the present Opposition spokesman on employment and industrial relations is best summed up by a comment that he made to a young CYSS participant at Shepparton in the wake of his decision to abolish the scheme. This young lady told him of her concern about the abolition of CYSS and of the fact that she had been unemployed for 18 months. His reply to her was: `You don't need a job, you need a psychologist'. With such an abysmal record of achievement and concern, we look forward with interest to the Opposition spokesman's espousal of how it would be different the second time around.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is nice to be back. My question is directed to the Treasurer. I refer to the Government's deal with the Australian Council of Trade Unions, announced on 4 September, in which the Government agreed to the payment of a 3 per cent productivity wage rise in the form of occupational superannuation payments to be met by employers. I ask the Treasurer: What does the word `productivity' mean in this context? How does it relate to the procuctivity of each individual shop, each factory, each office, each small business or, indeed, each abattoir? Under this deal do poor and ineffective workers and strikers get the same rewards as good and reliable workers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Back from the dead or otherwise, the shadow Treasurer fails to understand one of the basic central tenets of the operation of economic policy under the accord in the context of a centralised wage fixing system and economic policy generally. The profit share in this country, having been destroyed and therefore being inadequate to maintain investment at levels to absorb the new entrants to the labour force and to repair and maintain decent levels of employment, has been restored to its highest level for 15 years as a result of the growth in the economy which the Government has been able to secure. At no time did the previous Government have any prospect of getting the profit share back to the levels which this Government has succeeded in achieving.

ANSWER.PARA: The question implies that having now returned to the historic peak of the gross operating surplus in gross domestic product, the Government should see that no productivity is paid to the workers and that we should go from here to another historical norm--

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that. The question does not imply that.

—Yes, that is what it implies. The honourable member is saying that the productivity which has already been distributed to profits in the last two and a half years should continue to be distributed to profits. We on this side of the House reject that concept absolutely. We are not about moving to a new historical high for profits and therefore, not unreasonably, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, under the principles established by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission two and a half years ago, set down a productivity hearing on the economy. With these rates of growth in productivity it is not unreasonable that some of the benefits should go to the work force.

ANSWER.PARA: Because of the depreciation, the ACTU has failed to push its case for productivity which it had in mind-that is, pressing for costs to begin from 1 July 1985. Under this agreement, this is now deferred until 1 July 1986. Not only that, the agreement is on the basis of 3 per cent, not 4 per cent, and is spread over two years. Given the fact that not all members of the work force will pick it up, the Government has agreed to develop a safety net scheme towards the end of the process; so it is even feasible that the 3 per cent could be spread over three years or about one per cent a year. That is in the face of 5 per cent economic growth.

The implicit proposition in the question is that this should not be the case. It has completely eluded the Opposition that if this 3 per cent were paid as wages, the whole onward movement of occupational superannuation, which has been on for years, would still move through the economy and the result would be that the level of wage restraint and cost restraint which the ACTU has agreed to in this arrangement with the Government would not be there and, therefore, there would not be an appropriate wages response to the depreciation.

Because the Government has established a centralised wage fixing system again, because it has a planned approach to the whole question of national income shares, because it has repaired the profit shares which the `great men of business' opposite were unable to do and because the trade union movement has enough good sense to sit down with a government that is interested in speaking to the unions and say `yes, we have had strong economic and employment growth from this Government and we see an advantage in moving occupational superannuation through the economy so that all workers, privileged or otherwise, should enjoy it' the introduction of such a scheme will now be at a pace which allows the economy to afford it and will provide flexibility so that it moves first in the industries which are most able to afford it and to pay it.

It is on that basis that the difference between this Government's policies and the policies of the former Government, enshrined in every attitude expressed by the Leader of the Opposition and his shadow spokesman for the Treasury, provides such a stark contrast in the management of the macroeconomy and the shares which go to the growth operating surplus, to companies, to investment and to the work force. Because there will be no recanting by honourable members opposite from their lunatic policies of the 1970s and early 1980s, the Australian public will always have a very clear choice between the politics and the policies of prosperity and the politics of gloom and disaster typified in the honourable member's question.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. The Minister would be aware of some misinformed criticism in the community of this Government's commitment to maintaining an effective repatriation system. Will he reassure the veteran community that the changes that have been announced will not disadvantage the needy and the deserving and will enhance the Government's ability to improve the benefits and services now provided?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to give the honourable member the reassurance that is sought and to indicate that this Government does not flinch in any way from its commitment over many years to maintain an effective and generous repatriation system for servicemen and their wives and children. Some mischievous allegations have been made in respect of this matter, and the facts ought to be brought before the House. In the three Budgets introduced by the Hawke Government, spending on veterans' affairs has increased in general terms by 40 per cent and, after allowing for inflation, has involved an increase of 20 per cent-one of the largest increases in any portfolio in this Government. In real money terms, that amounts to an extra $1 billion, of which approximately $450m extra has been allocated to the payment of service pensions, $120m extra has been allocated to the payment of disability pensions, and $140m extra has been allocated to the payment of war widows' pensions. Most of the remainder has been allocated to medical treatment and urgent upgrading of repatriation hospitals, many of which fell into a disgraceful state because of the attitude of honourable members opposite.

ANSWER.PARA: As an illustration of the generosity of our repatriation system-because it must be looked at in a broad context-I point out that Australia pays between two and three times as many war widows' and disability pensions, relative to the size of our ex-service population, as does Britain, New Zealand, Canada or the United States of America. On the repatriation hospital side, the Government readily acknowledges its commitment to veterans. We are committed to the development of facilities necessary to meet the inevitable increase in demand for treatment of the aging veteran population. The Government commissioned the Brand report on the repatriation hospital system, which recommended upgrading of facilities and increased staffing. The Minister will shortly be placing those recommendations before the Government for further consideration.

In the last two Budgets spending on hospitals, including civil works, increased by 26 per cent to $56m. In 1985-86 there will be a further increase of $19.8m. In the honourable member's own State, developments at the Repatriation General Hospital, Concord, announced in the Budget, include the following: An operating suite of six theatres and support facilities, a central sterilising and supply department, an extended pathology department and a new store. Total spending on improvements at the Repatriation General Hospital at Concord is $17.6m. Tenders and work are to commence in 1985-86. Clearly, spending of this magnitude can be sustained only if the Government takes steps to ensure that resources are concentrated on the needy and the deserving. I can reassure the honourable member that amendments to the legislation will substantially enhance the Government's capacity to assist such beneficiaries in the future, just as we are doing at present in this Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Treasurer the current status of the Prime Minister's pre-election undertaking and his April commitment that interest rates would fall this year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have made it plain on a number of occasions in the House that I make no prediction about interest rates, particularly since the depreciation of the Australian dollar. It is a measure of the dishonesty of the Leader of the Opposition that, in sharing the platform with me where I was asked a question, he knows perfectly well, in the context of the remark to which this question refers, that I said that I agreed with most market commentators at the time. This was before the depreciation. This is a fairly typical question from the Opposition. What is surprising is that this new dry Opposition, this Opposition which is about to see prices set in the market, is apparently not prepared to see prices set for money in the market. At the drop of a hat it will wallow in opportunism to suggest to the Government that by implication and explicitly in the past that the Government ought to rule interest rates by driving them down in the market. In other words, having regulated--
—You ought to have proper economic policy.

—We all know about the right honourable member's role in Cabinet. He was one of the greatest regulators of all time. He is always in there with the levers in his hands. The Opposition is now arguing that the so-called self-proclaimed champions of free enterprise should be proposing to the Government that in one of the most important markets of all, that is the market for money, there ought to be some action on the part of the Government to rule the market and not to let interest rates find their own level. This is in marked contrast to the former views proposed by the now Leader of the Opposition who has been saying all year that the Government has been running a loose monetary policy. In fact in July he said that the M3 figures:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . show an alarming collapse in monetary discipline by the Hawke Government. . . . This loose monetary policy . . .

He is urging a credit squeeze, seeking to have interest rates higher to respond to the economic demands, and the questioner is seeking some action by the Government to reduce interest rates. We, on this side of the House, believe that interest rates will be set on commercial criteria in the market. That has always been our position. Of course the Government has met the current economic conditions with the appropriate policy response. We have seen a dramatic decline in the Commonwealth Budget deficit of $1.8 billion to around $5 billion for this year in prospect, or down from 3.3 per cent of gross domestic product to 2.2 per cent. In other words we have more than halved the disastrous fiscal imbalance and fiscal inheritance of the former Treasurer and diminished demands by the Commonwealth on markets. We got the Loan Council into some sort of equilibrium after the former Government allowed the States to run wild in terms of their borrowings, and we re-established the global limit. For our second year we have again secured agreement by the States to reduce their borrowings. The result will be that the public sector borrowing requirement will be reduced by about 1.5 per cent of GDP to 5.6 per cent.

Bank lending is still running very strongly in the economy. I notice that for the month of July it ran at a rate of 25 per cent higher than that of a year earlier. In other words, interest rates have not slowed down the real economy. It takes two to set a price. Obviously, people have been prepared to pay the price by borrowing to invest. That is in contrast to the situation during the honourable member for Bennelong's tenure as Treasurer when people were paying high prices to hang on and when they were borrowing money from the non-bank financial sector at very high rates simply to stay solvent. Now, they are borrowing by choice to invest. Interest rates are always one of the tools which ration money in the market. With the strong growth facing the economy now, that rationing in the market is appropriate and, therefore, our interest rate structure is set in the market in the face of all of those conditions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Communications aware that the new Leader of the Opposition has foreshadowed a proposal to subject Telecom Australia operations to taxation? If so, will the Minister advise the House of the consequences that would arise from such a policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Burke for his question. I am aware that the Leader of the Opposition has indicated his willingness to impose taxation on Telecom, although, as with so many of the other statements relating to the privatisation argument, the details are characteristically vague. As many honourable members would be aware, the Vernon Commission of Inquiry into the Australian Post Office in recommending the establishment of Telecom and Australia Post as independent, commercially orientated statutory authorities also recommended that both bodies be tax exempt. This recommendation was based on the desire to obtain the lowest possible charges for telecommunications and postal services within this country.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member for Bennelong, in a recent speech at the National Press Club before he became Leader of the Opposition, asserted that he would make Telecom subject to taxation. As a result of that statement, I found it necessary to ask for some estimates to be prepared on the effect of such a proposal on Telecom's revenue and the consequent increases in tariffs that would be necessary to maintain telecom's capital works and other maintenance programs at current levels.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does the National Party think of this?

—I will deal with that in a moment. I have been informed that imposition of taxes would have subjected Telecom to an additional liability of at least $400m for the financial year 1984-85. I am also advised that to say the least, this would require a substantial increase across the board in Telecom's tariffs, including, using conservative estimates, an increase of 6c in the cost of local calls. that is an increase of approximately 40 per cent. That would involve the largest increase in telephone charges in the history of the telephone services in this country.

ANSWER.PARA: The most recent household expenditure survey has shown that increases in telephone costs fall more regressively across income groups than do most other items of private consumption. In other words, the implementation of the proposal of the Leader of the Opposition would penalise the poorest and least privileged members of Australian society. Leaving aside the consequences following the destruction of the cross subsidy, about which there has been discussion and there will be plenty more in this place, one wonders when the new Opposition spokesman on communications will make a statement on this matter or whether he will passively accept this hard right doctrinaire nonsense.

Honourable members will await pronouncements with considerable interest. There was an interjection from the honourable member for Calare. I cannot help but ask: When will members of the National Party stand up to be counted on this issue? Apart from the Leader of the National Party who, in a knee-jerk reaction, came out supporting privatisation, the silence from the National Party on this issue has been deafening.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —We have one spokesman opposite who is prepared to say to his constituents that he will privatise and thus probably increase bills per subscriber every year by between $200 and $400. Let them know about that! That unofficial pronouncement, on behalf of the National Party, is probably a very appropriate point at which to end the discussion.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister whether, in an address to a business luncheon in Adelaide on 20 November 1984, he said:

QUESTION.PARA: Australia and Australians will during 1985 reap the interest rate rewards that are flowing from the successful policies of the past 20 months.
I also ask him whether he went on to say:
We've ploughed the fields and sown the seeds. In the very near future we will harvest the crop.

In view of the fact that interest rates have gone up across the board by at least one per cent to 2 per cent since November 1984 and the Prime Minister reaffirmed that promise after a substantial devaluation of the Australian dollar, will he please tell us when the crop will be harvested?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are very few areas on which we need to be lectured in any way by those opposite, particularly the Leader of the Opposition. If he wishes to talk about the harvesting of the crop, let us look at the crop that is being harvested. I remind honourable members that when I spoke on that occasion I was not speaking about just one element of the total range of macro-economic policy; I was talking about the whole range. So I am quite happy to have an accounting of the harvest of the application of that total economic policy.

ANSWER.PARA: Not only am I happy to have that accounting; I am also more than happy to have that accounting of our harvesting compared with the miserable returns when Opposition members went out to reap. The people who suffered when they went out to collect the results of the application of their policies were the 160,000 additional people who, in the last 12 months of their stewardship, had their jobs taken away from them. The people who harvested the results of the application of Opposition members' policies in the last 12 months they were in government were the additional 250,000 unemployed. At the same time as Opposition members were adding to the list of unemployment in their harvesting they achieved the unique distinction-unique in the literal sense of the word-that never before in the history of this country had there been simultaneous double digit inflation and double digit unemployment. Opposition members talk about bringing in a harvest of reduced inflation. That was the way they were going to solve the unemployment problem. They failed not only on the inflation front, because when they left office they left us with double digit inflation of 11.2 per cent; at the same time they left us with the highest harvest of unemployment, as a result of the application of their policies, that this country had seen in 50 years.

Any time that the Leader of the Opposition wants to have an accounting-a harvesting, if you like-of the application of economic policies, we will give it to him. We will not only rely on our account of what is happening in this country. We will also do what Opposition members suggested in this area in 1983-84-we will ask them to look at the judgment of the harvesting by the international community. Opposition members said in 1983 and 1984 that the international community would mark Australia down because its economic policies would fail. They know that the fact is that the international community is now saying that this economy is operating better than any other economy in the rest of the world. I am quite happy to go back to what I said in a speech I made in Adelaide in 1984. All the predictions we made in regard to the overall impact of our economic policies were right.

I give one example of how members of the Opposition could never get it right. They were the worst economic predictors when they were in office and they have kept their record going in Opposition. I remind the Opposition of what it said on 23 September 1983 in a statement relating to the national wage increase which was the first post-pause rise. This was the Opposition's area of expertise-wages policy and employment. It said:
the inevitable result must be that more people will lose their jobs . . . Today's outcome must put the Government even further from its election promise to create 500,000 new jobs in three years.

We are harvesting the result of our policies now. We have created 410,000 new jobs since we have been in office. We will more than exceed our target of 500,000 new jobs. The Leader of the Opposition could not get it right when he was in government. He cannot get it right in opposition. The ultimate tragedy of his not being able to get anything right is that he has not learnt. He is promising now that, if ever the people of Australia are mistaken enough to give him the opportunity again, he would give them exactly the same prescription. They have experienced the harvesting of his policies. They do not want it again. Fortunately, they will not be given the opportunity.

PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
International Year for Repairing the Earth
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That, for our survival, an effective World peace Initiative needs to be established which will work towards mutual understanding, world disarmament, economic well-being for all, fulfilling employment, a sustainable society conserving natural resources and revitalising soils essential for growing a plentiful and healthy food supply and tree cover. By achieving these objectives, Australia can set an example for the rest of the world to follow.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will:
1. Create an Australian Ministry for Peace specifically devoted to peace-building and the non-violent resolution of conflict;
2. Convene a national Summit for Survival to discuss the issues of world disarmament, security and national and international co-operation;
3. Fully support the United Nations World Disarmament Campaign by allocating the equivalent of at least 10% of the defence budget to fund peace activities;
4. Actively assist the International Year of Peace in 1986 by initiating programs for peace education, self-help development and environmental repair;
5. Develop national employment programs to give priority to the planting and growing of forests, food-producing trees and other crops;

6. Implement national recycling programs to reuse water and to compost all presently wasted sewage-sludge and organic garbage into hygienic humus, a natural fertiliser, for use in rehabilitating impoverished soils;
7. Propose to the United Nations General Assembly that 1989 be declared International Year for Repairing the Earth.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale and Mr Shipton.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and the future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritence of the fruits of hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they wish as a people to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that:

1. repeal the assets test legislation;
2. institute a broad inquiry into Australia's retirement income and taxation systems; and

3. following the receipt of the report of such an enquiry implement a retirement incomes policy which is fair and equitable, encourages self-provision and will be non-discriminatory in its operation and impact.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Burr and Mr Miles.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned electors, are deeply concerned at the possibility of an increase in indirect taxation currently being considered by the government.
To pose a broadly based consumption tax would mean a proportionately greater burden on low income groups and worsen their already precarious and impoverished position.

Women who are supporting mothers, together with their children, are acknowledged as the largest single group forced to exist below the poverty line. As beneficiaries of an already inadequate government pension, their futures would be even more jeopardised if there were to be a change towards increased broadly based consumption taxation.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Federal government not adopt the proposed shift towards increased indirect taxation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will every pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we are greatly concerned with the extent to which serious crime including murder, major drug financing and massive tax frauds have penetrated into the highest levels of Australian society as shown by the investigations of various Royal Commissions and in particular by Mr Frank Costigan Q.C.

That we are concerned that the National Crime Authority has too many restrictions and possible lines of veto placed upon it for it to be an effective successor to the Costigan Enquiry and that this will allow major criminals to avoid prosecution.

PETITION.TITLE: Excise on Beer
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
The Labor Government's policy of automatically increasing the excise applying to beer and therefore its price,
eliminates the opportunity for public or parliamentary debate on a tax increase,
perpetrates inflation,
reduces job opportunities in the hotel and brewing industries,
And your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
immediately repeal those legislative provisions that automatically increase the excise on beer when the C.P.I. increases.

that the Prime Minister, the Hon. R. J. PETITION.TITLE: Social Security and Repatriation Assets Test Abolition Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's failure to act to correct the anomalies in the Assets test on pensions, brought to its attention prior to the Assets Test's introduction on 21st March 1985, this legislation should be repealed before it has an unduly unfair impact on pensioners.

Further measures be taken in association with States to protect Australians, particularly women and children, from exploitation; and

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

Request the federal Government to immediately re-enact the previous laws which banned the entry into Australia and the sale of hard-core pornography and violence in video and publication form.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

(1) We are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian national flag;

The Union Jack-itself the creation of 3 Christian crosses-represents the nation's historical origin, and the source of its language and law.
The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space.
The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.

PETITION.TITLE: North Queensland: Radio Reception
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker, and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of Australia respectfully showeth:

that ABC radio transmission from 4QA Mackay is antiquated and operates on transmitters installed in 1947-48 to service a region in which the area and population has doubled in the intervening 36 years,

the signal from 4QA is below strength so that station 4QN at Townsville has a far better signal strength into the Mackay hinterland than 4QA, a distance of only 70 km from Mackay and over 300 km from Townsville,
the 4QN news programmes are of no interest in the Mackay region and in emergency situations such as cyclones, the 4QA frequency has limited penetration within the region,

that while FM programmes are available in Rockhampton and Townsville, Mackay, with a regional population of 100 000 people, has been by-passed when towns of smaller size have the advantages of FM radio.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government and the Department of Communications will move urgently to rectify both these anomalies.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled this humble petition of citizens of Australia respectfully showeth.

The richest 2000 people own as much as the poorest 2 1/4 million . . . It is a travesty in these circumstances that 2 million people are living in poverty in this country (Bob Hawke 11.7.81 Sydney Morning Herald)
The present provision of Social Benefits is absolutely inadequate . . . locking recipients into poverty (including 800,000 children of those on social welfare pensions or benefits).
To enable all Australians to share in the wealth of their country we call on the Australian Government in the forthcoming taxation reform to . . .
1. Raise the tax threshold to $10,000.
2. Double the permissable income ($30 to $60) plus indexation.
3. All pensions and benefits to be raised to 30% of the male average weekly earnings and indexed to C.P.I.
4. Full standard pension to be paid on an individual basis to eliminate the discrimination against married couples currently losing $30 per week.

Furthermore . . . we strongly oppose the introduction of a broad based indirect tax, thereby shifting the tax burden onto those dependent on social welfare and low income earners . . . further increasing their poverty while allowing continuation of high income earners and tax avoiders to pay little or no tax . . .

PETITION.TITLE: Sugar Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows that:

We request the Right Honourable Robert Hawke, Prime Minister of Australia to convene a meeting with representatives of the major sugar exporting countries of the world (Australia, Brazil, Cuba and the E.E.C.) to initiate meaningful negotiations to reach agreement on world sugar on policy and price.

Further that the Prime Minister commence urgent talks at international levels to formulate a new international sugar agreement to be based on the existing productions levels of the exporting countries adjusted by whatever percentage necessary to reduce the difference in world sugar stocks between supply and demand to within 25 per cent.

That the Prime Minister request the State and Commonwealth Governments to provide across the board assistance measures for Cane Growers by way of a guaranteed minimum average price as previously requested for raw sugar production within mill peak in the 1985-86 season.

The amount of direct assistance to cane growers should be on a per ton of cane basis so as to bridge the difference between the price of cane actually paid and the price which cane growers would receive at the sugar price of $240 per ton 94nt.

That unless financial assistance is provided in the short term the long term viability of many efficient producers will be sacrificed. If this happens the very fabric of communities along the northern-eastern coast of Australia will be destroyed.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Small Business
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
Introduction of any additional capital gains taxes, wealth taxes or death duties is opposed on the grounds that:
they adversely affect the small and medium size businesses in Australia, including farms, destroying incentive and discouraging investment in this important area of the economy;
the Australian economy, and employment in particular, is heavily reliant on growth in small businesses;

any capital gains that might result when owners of small enterprises finally sell these assets are not ``windfall gains'', but the result of many hard years of work and sacrifice, with very little being taken out of the business or farm by way of salaries so that the maximum amount of money can be ploughed back into the business or farm to create growth and jobs;
the owners of small businesses and farms often depend on a capital gain-which are simply deferred salaries-when they eventally sell these assets to sustain them in retirement;

Your Petitioners request that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, will protect the rights of private enterprise and reject any inequitable additional taxes. And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

2. We are aware that it has an adverse affect on the living standards of the average wage earner of this country.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will: Propose and pass a motion that the price of petrol be reduced by 3c a litre in line with a commitment given by the now Prime Minister of Australia during the 1983 election campaign.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Price
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
1. THAT we are completely dissatisfied with the frequent and substantial increase in the price of petrol and diesel fuel.
2. THAT we are aware that these price increases have an adverse affect on the living standards of the average Australian wage earner.
3. THAT increases in fuel prices adds to farm costs and further reduces the average income per farmer which has already fallen to one-third of national earnings.

Your Petitioners therefore pray that the Government will immediately reduce the price of petrol by three (3) cents per litre in line with the commitment given by the now Prime Minister of Australia during the 1983 election campaign and take all possible action to prevent further increases occurring.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Silverton and Broken Hill Telephone Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That in November, 1983, Silverton residents, being within the thirty-two (32) kilometre range of the service town, Broken Hill, petitioned to have country-wide charges revoked.
Information was subsequently received from the Honourable Member of Parliament, Mr. Noel Hicks, in December, 1983, stating that Silverton telephone calls had been returned to local charges.

In August, 1984, a Telecom statement was received to the effect that following the installation of the automatic telephone exchange, calls to our service town would again be charged under country-wide calling rates.

As we are well within the thirty-two (32) kilometre limit and Broken Hill is our employment centre and service town, we feel that it is discriminative both against the residents of Silverton and those who have personal and business dealings with said residents.

As Telecom conceded that these charges were punitive, we respectfully suggest that the situation has not changed with the installation of the automatic telephones and that local call rates should still apply.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Identification Card Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
This petition of Australian residents shows that we strongly oppose the introduction of the ``Australia Card'' or any form of compulsory identity cards.

We believe that the introduction of identity cards will erode civil liberties; will create an increased risk of invasion of privacy; and will not result in any significant increase in Government revenue.
We call on the Parliament to immediately reject any proposals for the introduction of compulsory identity cards.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Enterprise Migrant Hostel, Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

We are concerned that the closure of the Enterprise Migrant Hostel will be detrimental to the long-term settlement prospects of migrants in Victoria as well as detrimental to Ethnic Communities who have settled in the Springvale area. In addition, the long-term development of commerce and industry in the area will be adversely affected.
We urge the Government to reverse this decision.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

In a country of Free Education it is confirmed that the Federal Government is now planning drastic fees increase for overseas students next year. The intention is to impose ``full cost fees''-about $10,000 per annum-possible by 1988.
We the undersigned, citizens of Australia and overseas students, respectfully declare our opposition to the discriminatory fees policy.
Our reasons are:

1. the Overseas Student Program brings in a multitude of benefits in cultural, political, educational and other terms. These benefits are gained on top of a net financial gain of A$5 million p.a. in foreign exchange;

2. the overseas student fees is a stepping stone to reintroduce fees for all students whereby the principle of education as a right for everyone will be subverted. We believe there should be free education for all;
3. overseas students are not rich. 62% of overseas students come from families with annual combined parental income of less than $15,000;
4. overseas students do not displace local students. They only make up a mere 3.4% of tertiary students (Goldring Report); and
5. as a developed country, Australia has an obligation to assist the Third World countries.
We call upon the House of Representatives to, as a matter of urgency, repeal the legislation imposing the discriminatory fees on overseas students.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Court
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will consider the plight of the father in the Family Court.
Fathers, according to the Laws of Australia, should have equal rights to their children, in both Custody and Access applications before the Family Court.

It should be made possible for fathers to be able to continue to be involved at all times throughout every stage of their children's development, thus being in the best interest of the children themselves, without incurring exorbitant legal costs.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of we, the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:

That we are concerned at the proposed withdrawal of Federal Funding from pre-school education. This is 20% of the pre-school budget. Thus it will be difficult to maintain existing programmes and impossible to provide pre-school education for those children not receiving it now. We urge the Commonwealth Government of Australia to maintain this funding.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The Petition of certain citizens, do strongly request the Federal Government to re-consider the proposal to cut funding for Pre-School Education.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray

PETITION.TITLE: Television Reception
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, undersigned electors of the Division of Barker respectfully showeth-

The quality of commercial television in the area, which is deplorable, has been further affected by the recent boosting of Victorian TV signals. Channels 9 and 10 have been almost obliterated by this boost. The impending introduction of Channel 8 to the area does not compensate, as its content is largely Victorian. South Australians wish to watch South Australian television.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the signal from Adelaide commercial television be boosted to cover a wider area and to regain channels lost by boosted signals from Channel 6 at Ballarat.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Baltic States: Human Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That on 28th February, 1985, the Senate passed a resolution that read:

(ii) that in order to do so the Australian Government should, on its own initiative, and by seeking the support of like-minded governments, bring the question of human rights and self-determination for the Baltic States before all appropriate forums of the United Nations and especially before the United Nations Human Rights Commission, and,
(iii) that the Department of Foreign Affairs should be directed to take all necessary steps in order to implement this Resolution.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Members and the House of Representatives will concur with that resolution.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
