Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray:
1. That all Governments throughout Australia acknowledge and protect the Right to Work on behalf of all Australians;
2. That the total sovereignty of individual governments be recognised as a fundamental requirement of a workable, balanced federal system of government;
3. That all necessary steps be taken to protect the citizens of Australia from any compulsion, threat or intimidation to join any trade union;
4. That the supremacy of elected governments over the sectional interests of trade unions be recognised, and
5. That the provision of essential services be maintained, free from industrial disruption.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection, storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving `property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schems overseas has had serious adverse effects, namely;
(i) a slowing down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled.

We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government, in re-structuring the taxation system, upholds as fundamental the principle of an equitable distribution of wealth among the people of our nation, and
1. That the Government does not levy any form of broadly based indirect or consumption taxation, and
2. That the Government does levy gift and death duties, excluding the family home from the latter, and a substantial tax on realised capital gains and wealth.

DEBATE.TITLE: NEW PRICES AND INCOMES ACCORD: EMPLOYMENT PROSPECTS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr N. A. Brown) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be subsmitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The damage to employment prospects arising from the new prices and incomes accord between the Government and the A.C.T.U.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The new prices and incomes accord now agreed to by the Government and ratified by the Australian Council of Trade Unions must be the final capitulation of this Government to the power of the ACTU. It represents the abandonment of any semblance of economic responsibility that this Government had. This Government's Budget strategy must now be in tatters, particularly insofar as the prospects for employment growth are concerned. It guarantees that Australia will now have high inflation and substantial wage increases-wage increases that will price Australia out of markets and our people out of jobs. It guarantees that unemployment will remain at high levels. Let it be said at the outset, before the Government starts crowing about this matter, that the Government's record on employment growth is nothing to be proud of. Any government which after such a period in office is still faced with unemployment levels of around 8.2 per cent should be more concerned with taking positive steps to improve employment than with scoring political points.

SPEECH.PARA: When we look at this tattered situation of the Government's policy we see what a capitulation there has been. Who can forget-this is as recently as 20 August-those noble words in the Budget Speech delivered only three weeks ago? The Government was parading its economic responsibility on the devaluation of the Australian dollar. It said that it was a bonus which it would use to turn around the Australian economy-a bonus that would restore our competitiveness and generate thousands of jobs. Above and beyond that, it was the first real test to which the accord between the Government and the ACTU was to be put. Who can forget the noble words of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) setting out the Government's response as it faced this real challenge? The Treasurer told us that the devaluation had restored our competitive edge. He said:
. . . it has made our goods cheaper in world markets and it has made it easier for our industries at home to compete with imports.
He went on to say:
If we are to do that, we cannot afford to allow our production costs to rise above those of our competitors.
Who could disagree with that? But the Treasurer went on to say:

If the initial and full price effects of the depreciation were to be transmitted to wages via indexation decisions, our cost increases would noticeably exceed those of our major competitors for years to come.

That is what the Treasurer said in his Budget Speech on 20 August, putting it without any equivocation whatsoever. He said that if the effects of depreciation of the dollar found their way into wages our cost increases would exceed those of our competitors, with all the economic disasters that that would entail, particularly the economic disaster of increased unemployment. The Treasurer put it as plainly as anyone could in that statement of the Government's economic policy for the whole of the Budget year. He said that the full price effects of the depreciation must not be transmitted into wages and that if that did happen we would lose our competitive edge. Listen to these prophetic words of the Treasurer at that time:
That is why, temporarily, we must modify our normal support for full wage indexation.

Of course, that was tepid enough, and we said so at the time. But has the Government lived up to that? Has it modified its normal support for full wage indexation? Of course it has not. It has not modified that support at all. It has done far worse than that; it has given its support for full wage indexation in the current national wage case; it has given away the next national wage case to boot and it has given away the productivity case.

Let us look a little at each of those in turn. What is the situation with regard to the present national wage case? The Government has entered into an alliance with the ACTU to argue before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission that there should be full wage indexation. It has committed itself to argue for full wage indexation knowing the consequences that must follow from that decision. In the course of doing so, it has thrown away all of the advantages that the devaluation gave us and all of the competitive edge that it was so keen to crow about on 20 August. Our cost increases must now exceed those of our major competitors. That must affect employment; it must affect investment. It will affect those things adversely and permanently. This is exactly what the Government, hand in hand with the ACTU, has argued that the Arbitration Commission should now do. The Government, together with the ACTU, is going to the Commission to argue in favour of exactly what the Treasurer warned us against in August-allowing the price effects of depreciation to be translated into wages and allowing full wage indexation. Let there be no doubt that this is what the Government has agreed to with the ACTU. Let us look at the words of the agreement. It states:
The Government and the ACTU will propose to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission that . . . full wage indexation apply in the current National Wage Case. . .

There can be no doubt that the Government has abandoned the position that it put in its Budget. It would be disastrous from an investment and employment point of view that the benefits of depreciation should find their way into indexation and that there should be full wage indexation in the current national wage case. There is no doubt that the Government has abandoned the position which it put in August and no doubt whatsoever that that abandonment is completely irresponsible and will give rise to very far reaching and serious economic consequences in this country.

What has intervened in this period to explain this remarkable turn of events? What has happened is that the Government has gone along, hand in glove with its paymaster, and has done another of its sordid deals. With this deal the Government has thrown away the competitive edge about which it was so keen to talk. It has not lowered our production costs, but increased them; it has not made our goods cheaper on world markets, but made them more expensive. It has not made it easier for our industries at home to compete with imports; it has made it more difficult for that to happen. It has guaranteed that Australia will have higher inflation eating away at people's savings and discouraging investment. Above all, it has dealt a cruel blow to those who had hoped that there were prospects for substantial employment growth as a result of the devaluation.

No doubt the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) will stand up and say in reply: `It is not as bad as this; we will have a 2 per cent discount from April 1986'. Let us look at what the Government has agreed upon with the ACTU. The agreement states that this 2 per cent discount relates to the direct contribution made by the depreciation to the increase of the consumer price index in both the first and second halves of the calendar year. The Government has given its endorsement, with all the authority of the national Government, to inflation roaring ahead until April 1986 and then will discount it by only 2 per cent of the inflation caused by the depreciation. There will full indexation for all other wage induced inflation, no matter how high it is. The Government has clearly committed itself to that and all of its consequences. Even then, there will be a discount of 2 per cent only for devaluation. What a flimsy defence that is. By then the damage will have been done. The Government has given its full endorsement to wage inflation from the present national wage case and well into 1986. It has given away any arguments for less than full indexation and full discounting for devaluation.

The Minister will say: `Look at what we have saved on the productivity case'. What has the Government saved on the productivity case, which was a claim for 4 per cent by the ACTU? The Government says, `Don't worry about the Arbitration Commission', but this will result in an increase of 3 per cent to be paid by superannuation from as early as July 1986. We say that it is a complete abuse of the arbitration system. This country cannot afford full wage indexation now, if we want full employment growth. TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's half Budget and its total economic strategy is the strategy of anachronistic corporatists playing out the last acts of the Industrial Revolution long after that era of economic history has truly passed. It is a strategy which, for all the rhetoric of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), is a strategy based on those tired old policies of big spending and deals with union bosses; a strategy which shows that the Government and indeed the Australian Labor Party as a whole are painfully ignorant of the inexorable socio-economic changes now taking place in Australia. Gone are the days when the Australian economy dependent on mass produced, low technology manufactured goods, an economy which spawned the corporatist institutional structure so favoured by the Labour Party. Today's and tomorrow's economy will depend increasingly on small efficient enterprises producing high quality mid-technology products and providing services and recreational facilities. This trend is already apparent in the United States of America. It is no coincidence that most of America's new jobs are in enterprises which employ fewer than 20 people.

SPEECH.PARA: In Australia the growing community pressure for deregulation and wage flexibility, the vociferous demands for tax relief, and the manifest frustration with government, particularly in the small business sector, are all symptomatic of the changing nature of the Australian economy and the failure of the Government and our institutional structure to recognise and encourage this change.

The Government's economic strategy, only partly revealed in the Budget, will in the longer term hold back our economy and guarantee for Australia a second rate future because it is based on public sector growth and deals made with the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The results already are that the dollar has plunged and we have a $10 billion current account deficit. Inflation is intensifying, the foreign debt is increasing and spending by governments is also increasing. So we have a growth generated by the public sector which is narrowly based and it is no surprise to hear small-business people all over Australia asking: `Why aren't I involved in this growth? Why am I not benefiting from what the Government describes as an upturn in the economy?' If the Government recognised the transmogrification of the economy it would have acted in its Budget to assist small business. It would have reduced small business costs through lower taxes, through initiatives to reduce interest rates and through lower taxes, through initiatives to reduce interest rates and through a more flexible approach to wages. It would have provided investment incentives for business, not taken them away. It would have made a clear commitment to economic stability through an appropriate monetary and anti-inflationary strategy. Instead, this corporatist Government offers almost the reverse. It has budgeted for a growth in government spending of 1.3 per cent in real terms, bringing the increase in spending since March 1983 to a staggering 41.3 per cent. This has ensured an excessive public sector borrowing requirement which this financial year will be 5.6 per cent of the gross domestic product, about twice that of the United States. It has also led, since 1983, to a 43 per cent increase in the public debt, which this year will attract an interest liability of $6.7 billion, or $20 a week for every employed person.

The consequences of Labor's spending spree for Australia's emerging, wealth generating small enterprises, are twofold. The concomitant public sector borrowing has forced interest rates up to their highest level in 50 years. Even the Labor Premier of South Australia recognised this when he said last week:
They-
meaning interest rates-
are getting to the stage where they are threatening the economic recovery . . . and they are `threatening business expansion . . . '

That is the view of a Labor Premier whose own record on spending is no better than that of the Federal Government's. Obviously high interest rates have a deleterious effect, in particular on the capacity of small business to borrow for investment. Whilst big business is relatively unconcerned, although it is not happy, about rising domestic interest rates because of its use of foreign currency and Euro-Australian dollar borrowing facilities, small business has none of these advantages. It is trapped. That is why last financial year business investment as a proportion of GDP was at a 10-year low, and it is why, in Budget Statement No. 2, Treasury has stated:
The recovery in business investment to date and in prospect in 1985-86 has not been strong historically . . .

The handmaiden of big government, which is of course high taxation, is also imposing unacceptable burdens on small enterprises. Pay as you earn tax receipts this year are to rise by 13.3 per cent. They will have risen by 29 per cent in just two years. On top of this massive increase in personal income tax at the end of the month we will have a tax package of what have been described by many as option A nasties.

How can we motivate small entrepreneurs and the work force with a tax burden like that? How can we motivate small enterprises with the imminent capital gains tax, a tax which, on American precedent, has proved to be an investment destroyer for small businesses? How can small enterprises be expected to prosper and to grow if employers who are already operating on narrow margins have to pay a fringe benefits tax?

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your experience of running a small business?

—But those are the consequences of Labor's corporatist big government strategy. A representative of that Party is rudely interjecting from the other side of the House. These are the consequences of its strategy and its passion for spending on the pet projects of vested interest groups, all at the expense of the wealth creators of the future. A government which recognised our changing society would have looked for ways to assist, not hinder, small enterprises. It would have produced constructive reforms to business taxation in order to help enterprises invest for the future-something this Government has not even considered even in its options A, B and C. It would have taken steps to eliminate invidious anti-business double taxation by reintroducing the dividend rebate. Yet this Government's strategy offers none of those things.

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from spending, the other centrepiece of Labor's corporatist strategy is its prices and incomes accord. The world of the accord is not the world of Australia's small, entrepreneurial, wealth-generating enterprises. No small enterprises participated in the recent negotiations on wage discounting and the future of the accord. The only role for small business in Labor's corporate structure is at the table of the Economic Planning Advisory Council, that long-forgotten and superfluous relic of the first summit. Indeed, so forgotten is EPAC that many of its senior staff are seeking alternative employment.

The new deal on wage discounting and productivity negotiated by the Government with the ACTU is a gutless surrender by the Government to the ACTU. So complete was the surrender that I am surprised that there are any members of the Government in this House today. I see there are only four. I assume that the rest of them are away at the annual conference of their high command in the Sydney Town Hall.

The Treasurer, in his Budget Speech just three weeks ago, stated unequivocally that the Government would support discounting for inflation at the next national wage case hearing. He told us that it was central to the Government's economic strategy. We now know that not only will he fail to proceed with his commitments but also, as a result, his total economic strategy is now in tatters. To use the words of the Confederation of Australian Industry, the Government `has failed to grasp the nettle'. The CAI stated:
. . . the ACTU has once again exploited its privileged position'.

The Government promised negotiations on discounting between the ACTU and the employers. The employers were not even consulted. The deal was struck at the behest of the ACTU. The Government has granted it a productivity increase in arrogant disregard for any opinions that the so-called independent umpire, the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, may have in the future. It has granted the productivity increase, despite the fact that over the last two years productivity per hour worked has fallen by 0.4 per cent. But, above all, the deal has been done with no thought whatsoever for our wealth-creating small business sector.

The new wages deal will exacerbate inflation. The Treasurer has implicitly admitted that. It will push up interest rates as inflationary expectations are relit, and that is already happening. It will destabilise our international reputation, as can be seen already in the further slump in the Australian dollar. It will impose an additional crippling burden on Australia's forgotten wealth creators, the small business sector.

The recent wages deal is another example of the Government's arrogant, anachronistic corporatism, a corporatism which is defying the inexorable evolution of the Australian economy. The tide of change-that tide which will generate long term prosperity and jobs for the whole community-is being resisted by the Labor Government. By resisting such change it is damaging our prospects for the future. But make no mistake, that inexorable tide will ultimately wash Labor's corporatism out into the ocean and the small enterprise based entrepreneurship will open up the future for all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Child Mrs J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1985 Budget is very much a good news-bad news Budget. It is good news for the people of Australia and bad news for the doomsayers in the Opposition. The third Keating Budget is built on the solid foundation of 2 1/2 years of spectacular economic growth, considerably reduced unemployment and inflation and a marked improvement in the competitiveness of our industry. Given the morass into which the economy had sunk by the start of 1983, the recovery brought about by this Government has been astounding.

SPEECH.PARA: However, before I look at the Government's record and its proposals for future development, it is worth while climbing abroad the memory train-the bad memory train-and revisiting those seven wasted years of coalition bumbling and fumbling. Who can forget the rubbery figures Budget, the now you see it now you don't tax cuts, the cold showers and bread and water philosophising? Who can forget the grandiose promises of Fraser on the campaign trail, the born to rule assurance that everything would be set to rights once our patrician betters were restored to their rightful position? What a blow it must have been for the Ministers of the Fraser Government to discover that the country no longer ran itself as it did back in the halcyon days of Sir Robert. How shattering it must have been to find that governing an industrial nation at a time of international economic turmoil meant making hard, often unpalatable, decisions.

It is small wonder that the Fraser Government was long on rhetoric and short on performance; small wonder that crackpot economic theorising abounded. After all, it is a great deal easier to win an esoteric argument about the virtues of the Laffer curve than to frame an economic policy that actually works in the real world, rather than in an academic wind tunnel.

Many coalition members, presumably those who had not heard of the Laffer curve, spent most of their time searching for scapegoats. Naturally, the Whitlam Government came in very handy for a long time. The union movement proved good value, as it always has for conservatives. At one stage, the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission was very much in vogue for scapegoat bashing. It was attacked by timid employers who were not prepared to be human sacrifices on behalf of the Government's wages policy, such as it was. Even Treasury was not exempt. Everyone copped the blame at some stage-everyone except the people who were elected to take the responsibility.

In 1983, the Australian electorate recognised that the coalition parties, far from being the sound and reliable managers of legend, were actually, in the words of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) a bunch of `mugs and hillbillies' who had frittered away seven years of power. The voters wisely chose to elect a government which was prepared to adopt a sensible economics strategy and stick to it. The fruits of this approach are now obvious.

Let me say something about the prices and incomes accord. A great deal of discussion has taken place in recent weeks concerning discounting of wage increases coming out of the national wage case. The Opposition parties-there is only one member of the Opposition here now--

TALK.START.PARA: —Two.

—I am sorry; the honourable member was hidden from view. The Opposition parties have been scarcely able to contain their delight because of their belief that conflict over the discounting question could have spelt the end of the accord. I did not believe that this was likely to happen, but is it not odd to note the Opposition's reaction? When the accord was first proposed, the Opposition opposed the concept bitterly. When the accord was put into operation, we were told that it would be the ruination of the country. When Opposition members perceived it as being threatened, they hoped to shed crocodile tears at the funeral. In reality, there is nothing magical or mystical about the accord. It is simply a concrete recognition of a philosophy of government-the philosophy that it makes good sense to try to get the various interest groups in this community to sit down in a civilised manner to look for ways to work together. The philosophy is based on the recognition that the men and women who lead the trade union movement and the men and women who run Australian industry are essentially people of good will who have the interests of their country at heart. It simply would never occur to a coalition government to try to hammer out a consensus approach to important community issues.

SPEECH.PARA: Conservatives automatically assume that everyone else in the community has the same cynical and grasping approach as themselves, and would never be prepared to give a little for the benefit of all. Their other consideration would be, of course, that open public discussion might oblige them to actually argue their point of view, rather than relying on speeches written for them by their advisers. As the saying goes: `It is better to remain silent and be thought a fool than to speak and remove all doubt'.

I think it reflects great credit on the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer in particular that they have been prepared to adopt such an open approach to these matters rather than hiding in their offices and concocting policies in the dark. It is never going to be possible to get total agreement on very complex issues, but it cannot but help if one can persuade people to put their cards on the table. This is a high risk strategy in that any error one makes is more likely to be on public display. However, when all is said and done, what really matters are results and, on this score, the Government has much to be proud of.

I want to say something about the Opposition's new glamour issue of privatisation. To put it in a nutshell, privatisation appears to encompass taking efficient, profit making organisations in the public sector and selling them so that someone other than the taxpayers can make money from them. Apparently, the taxpayers are going to be grateful for this, but is a bit difficult to understand why. As I understand it, the traditional criticism of the public sector from the conservative parties was that public enterprises were inefficient and cost the taxpayers money to subsidise their operations. Now it appears that inefficient public enterprises are quite all right, it is the efficient ones that are to be disposed of.

The privatisation policy is justified by a good deal of rhetoric about the role of the state as against the individual, the dangers of monopoly power and a lot of other pretentious nonsense, but the real point of the exercise is apparently to allow the coalition parties' mates to make a quick quid. John Valder pretty much gave the game away when he pointed out on one of his famous tapes that one should only dispose of bodies that made a profit. He could not see any point in selling the others. I suppose that if the Opposition was to argue that all government activities that could feasibly be undertaken by private enterprise should be sold off, it would at least have the virtue of consistency. However, it is quite clear that what is intended is that the eyes will be picked out of bodies such as Telecom and Australia Post.

Everyone knows that Telecom and Australia Post are obliged to provide an enormous range of services to the whole community. Some such as the Australia Post courier service and the Sydney-Melbourne subscriber trunk dialling routes are highly profitable. Others, such as telegrams and telephone connection in outback areas, operate heavily in the red. I would imagine that the National Party would be interested in that. Nonetheless, these services are still provided because of the clear social need for them. They cannot be provided at cost because almost no-one could afford to pay the huge amounts involved. Accordingly, cross-subsidisation is employed; that is, the profits from those services which do make money are used to subsidise those which do not. That seems to me to be a fair and reasonable situation.

What will become of this system under privatisation? What will become of unprofitable, but essential, services if the profitable services are sold to private enterprise? There are only two possibilities: The economic cost could be charged, imposing heavy burdens on people outside the capital cities. Again, let us hear from the National Party on this matter. That would go down well in National Party seats. The alternative is for the taxpayer to be slugged in order to subsidise uneconomic services. I thought that the so-called economic rationalists on the Opposition benches were in favour of less taxation, not more. If Opposition members really believe that privatisation is going to capture the imagination of the Australian electorate, they may have another think coming. Most Australians are sensible enough to recognise that there are some services which are simply not appropriate for private interests to handle. When profit becomes the prime motive, someone has to pay the price.

By and large, public enterprises in this nation do not have any record of massive inefficiency compared with private enterprises. Conservatives always talk about the railways as an example. Because the Australian Government runs the railway systems they lose money. Of course they do. So does every railway system in the world, public and private. Some services that governments are obliged to provide in the public interest are such that they cannot be expected to run at a profit. Surely the concept of the public interest still means something to those who sit opposite. If it does not, they are going to sit opposite for a long time. However, that is not an argument that needs to be put in defence of the record of organisations such as Qantas Airways Ltd, Trans Australia Airlines or the Commonwealth Bank. These are all organisations which more than pay their way and have no need at all to be embarassed about their commercial performance. To sell them off, probably to foreign interests, would be short sighted economic vandalism.

I made mention of the National Party a couple of minutes back. Perhaps some more comments would be appropriate. Members of the National Party in this House talk loud and long about the wastefulness of government spending. They say: `Slash the deficit. Sack the public servants! Cut spending to the bone!' One might be inclined to take all this fervour about government extravagance seriously, but it always pays to look below the surface of the National Party.

We are all aware of the desire of members of the National Party to-in the classic phrase of I think it was Kim Beazley senior-`socialise their losses and capitalise their gains'. Are they really serious about economising and cutting government spending? The honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) cannot be very serious. He has a motion on notice calling on the Government to build aged units and provide more hostel and nursing home beds in no less than nine cities and towns in his electorate. What is more, he would like it all this year. He may not be aware that the average cost to the Commonwealth for the establishment of a nursing home is $15m, and he wants nine this year. The honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) is a little less ambitious. He wants us to spend only $15m to upgrade and seal a trunk road in his electorate. The honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) does not muck about. He wants the Government to upgrade to four lanes the Bruce Highway from Brisbane to at least as far north as the Kenilworth turnoff. It is a commendable idea, but the cost would be staggering. Given the hilly terrain and the number of bridges required the Government would need to spend between $600m and $1 billion. When one adds amounts like this to the endless list of subsidies and bounties always being demanded by the National Party spokesmen, it is easy to see what would happen to the deficit with them at the helm.

One of the most interesting features of this Budget has been the reaction of the media. The nature of the media is such that it generally accentuates the negative. Bad news is usually thought to be more interesting than good news and criticism thought to be more newsworthy than praise. This Budget has proved to be an exception to the rule. It is not often that Labor governments attract a lot of praise from the Press, especially on economic issues. So I am sure that the House will bear with me if I share with it some of the views of the Press. Terry McCrann, business editor of the Age, and generally an acerbic critic of this Government, said:

Mr Keating-and Cabinet-deserve great credit for last night's document. All things considered, especially the political realities, so often ignored by economic purists, and setting aside the inevitable quibbles, Mr Keating has brought down just about the best Budget he could have.
Peter Cole Adams, of the same newspaper, said:
Last night's was not an exciting Budget, but it made a lot more sense than most that were brought down over the past 15 years.
The Australian Financial Review described the Budget in the following terms:
As realistic a document as could sensibly be expected under current circumstances . . . a serious and largely non-ideological effort to put a responsible philosphy into effect.
Even the Australian could not bring itself to be unkind:
It would be unfair to suggest that, on balance, this Budget does not evidence a serious attempt to confront our basic economic problems.
The view of the Canberra Times was as follows:
Overall, last night's Budget represents a good effort by the Government to build on Australia's economic recovery so far and to make substantial gains during the current financial year.
Would not one know that the only real sour note would come from the discredited former Treasury Secretary and intellectual guru of the new Right, Mr John Stone?

TALK.START.PARA: —He is losing credibility, eh?
—Yes, he is. Writing in the Sydney Morning Herald, Mr Stone said:

SPEECH.PARA: Why therefore, reading the Budget Speech and its associated papers, does one have this strangely uneasy feeling? . . . Basically the queasiness derives from the other theme so predominantly displayed in the Speech-Stepping up welfare spending . . . No less than six full pages are devoted to a wearisome catalogue of how much more of our money the Government now proposes to spend in a bewildering array of new so-called job creation programs.
How typical of Mr Stone to find job creation programs wearisome.

In conclusion, I refer to the extraordinary events which took place in the Liberal Party last week. I picked up a newspaper-I think it was the Melbourne Sun News Pictorial-which blared on the front page ` ``Howard's Out'' says Peacock' and which said on the back `Snedden Out'. I became quite disoriented. I did not know at which end to start. There have been many suggestions that many Liberal members of parliament did not understand the consequences of their vote on the deputy leadership. If that is really the case, I can readily understand why the honourable member for Kooyong tossed it in. Who would want to lead a pack like that, a pack who did not even know what the result of their vote would foreshadow? Now that some of these masterminds have caught up with the news they have convinced themselves that they have done the right thing after all. Certainly, the Opposition's previous conveyance was looking a little worse for wear. However, the new one already has a lot of miles on the clock. The Leader now is the same man who was Malcolm Fraser's right hand man and who presided as Treasurer over five of the most dismal years in this country's economic history. It is hardly the wave of the future. I commend the Government and, in particular, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on this Budget. It is one which I am sure will lead to greater prosperity and security for all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, honourable members and fellow Australians: If moving to a new seat on the back bench of this honourable and historic chamber is the price I have to pay for my loyalty to my former Leader, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), it is a price I pay gladly. I have no regrets whatsoever. I am not a whinger; I am not a squealer. I do not turn back and I do not look over my shoulder. I have offered precisely the same loyalty to the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), who is the new Leader of the Parliamentary Liberal Party. As I said earlier today, being returned to the back bench is a bit like a sort of parliamentarian's purgatory.
—It is good for humility.

—It is good for humility. I will do my time, and I will bide my time. I come from a family whose parliamentary involvement in Tasmania goes back to 1893 when the first Hodgman was elected to the Tasmanian House of Assembly. The Honourable T. C. Hodgman, MHA, was a very great member of the Tasmanian Parliament. It surprised many when he opted to remain in State politics and declined the gilt-edged invitation to enter the House of Representatives at Federation. He continued to serve with very great distinction in the Tasmanian Parliament until World War I. The Honourable T. C. Hodgman, MHA, was one of the old school. He had strict and very fundamental principles and values. They were basically the values of Australian politics for his generation. Honour, loyalty, character and propriety were the order of the day. Of all these values, honour and loyalty were placed highest. I acknowledge the presence in the chamber of my very close colleague and friend the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck), whose loyalty to me over the last few days has been a very great strength to me.

SPEECH.PARA: When upheavals occur in party politics it is traditional for the victims to take their punishment in silence, to go quietly and not make a fuss. What a lot of bunkum! At the request of my former Leader, the honourable member for Kooyong, I have pledged my loyalty to the new Leader, notwithstanding any private views I have as to his election to the highest office the Parliamentary Liberal Party can offer. That I remained totally loyal to the former Leader is something of which I am proud-very proud indeed. I can look him in the eye and say with an utterly clear conscience that he had my total loyalty-150 per cent-from start to finish, until the moment he directed me to transfer that loyalty to his successor.

What must have hurt the honourable member for Kooyong tremendously is the obvious fact that some of those close to him and, I might say, senior to me, did not maintain their loyalty. I believe that the honourable member for Koo- yong took his demise with very great character, very great grace and extraordinary dignity. That he did so when he must have known in his inner- most heart that he had been brought down by disloyalty, dishonour and downright treachery will stand as an abiding monument to his total and absolute commitment to the Liberal Party of Australia which he has served with great distinction since he first joined at the age of 15 years. For my own part I salute him. I believe that he has been overgenerous to those who brought him down. It is the closest thing that I have seen in my life to the great imperative `To err is human, to forgive, divine'.

Before members of the Hawke socialist Government opposite feel pleasure, let me remind this honourable House and the people of Australia that nothing which has occurred within the last few days can come within cooee of the brutal, unprincipled and sadistic assassination of the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Hayden) at the hands of the usurper and imposter who currently holds, by fraud, the office of Prime Minister of Australia. The despicable assassination of the honourable member for Oxley in the shadows of the ides of March in 1983 will go down in the history of Australian politics as probably the greatest case ever of infamy, disloyalty and treachery.

I mentioned earlier my compliance with the request by the honourable member for Kooyong that I transfer my loyalty to the new Leader. This I have done, as he well knows. He, for his part, has stated that if he fails to deliver the goods anybody-I repeat, anybody-can covet his position. I have noted his comments with interest. I accept the conditions which he has laid down. If he delivers the goods he has nothing to fear. He is now set on a course which should, in my opinion, take him and the Liberal Party to victory at the next Federal election. In that he will have my total and absolute support because nothing is dearer to my heart than to participate in not just the destruction but the utter annihilation of the Hawke socialist Government at the earliest possible opportunity. I am already relishing it in anticipation.

When the Government goes it will not just be a defeat; it will be a rout. It will be absolutely decimated as it deserves to be. If the new Leader delivers the goods, as I anticipate he will, it follows therefore that he will be victorious and his position will be secure. If, however, he does not deliver the goods not only will I covet his position but also, as the natural and logical alternative to him, I will take it from him. Let me make that absolutely clear so that nobody is in any doubt at all as to precisely where I stand.

What has happened to me in the past 24 hours is just a hiccup in my parliamentary career. I continue as the Federal member for Denison, proud to represent the finest electorate in Australia. Notwithstanding the Hawke socialist Government's electoral redistribution injustice of 1984, I held that seat against all the odds. The most sophisticated computer print-out before last year's Federal election rated my chances of holding the seat at only 31 per cent. In truth I am proud to be a Liberal representative of what on paper is clearly a Labor seat. At about 8.20 p.m. on election night at the Australian Labor Party headquarters members of that Party were popping the champagne corks with the jubilant cries: `Hodgman is gone'. By 9 p.m. they were struggling to put the corks back into the bottles as they realised to their dismay that I was not gone at all. Later that night the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was reported as having described me as the `Harry Houdini of Australian politics'.

I have said many times before that winners never quit and quitters never win. When the going gets tough the tough get going. That is precisely what I will do from this point on. I am just 46 years of age-I think a very young 46 years of age. When the great R. G. Menzies was 46 years of age he was Prime Minister of Australia. The year was 1940 and Australia was at war. In 1941, just one year later, his Government fell and Menzies, in disgrace, was replaced as Prime Minister of Australia by John Curtin. Just eight years later, in December 1949, Menzies rose like a phoenix from the ashes and again became Prime Minister of Australia, going on to set the record, which will never be broken, as Australia's longest serving Prime Minister.

Coming close to home, in 1971 the Rt Hon. Malcolm Fraser, by his own resignation, plummeted from the very high position of Minister for Defence to the lowly back bench. Many so-called experts predicted at that time the demise of his parliamentary career. His future looked bleak and it was claimed around the corridors of Parliament House that he had just one friend in the entire parliamentary Liberal Party-the honourable member for Corangamite, the Hon. Tony Street. History shows that, just four years later, Malcolm Fraser became Prime Minister of Australia, inflicting upon the ALP the most devastating defeat it had ever suffered. He won government in an election which set a record with the largest government majority since Federation. People had said that he was gone and they had said that he was finished but he proved them wrong.
I am not gone. I am not finished. I will endure this hiccup in my parliamentary career. I will see it through.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. I would like to know when the honourable member will stop talking about himself and start talking about the people and poverty.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—We have a soft spot for the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services but the sooner he is put into an old men's home the better for all of us. As I have said, I am young and virile. I repeat: I am not gone; I am not finished. I will endure this hiccup in my parliamentary career. I will see it through. I have been in State and Federal parliaments since 14 May 1966.
—My birthday.

—The honourable member for Franklin's birthday and my father's birthday. On the subject of my father, I would just like to say, in case honourable members opposite think I am friendless, when I arrived at the Sheraton Hotel in Brisbane last night there was a telegram for me which simply said: `Some people have no taste. We still love you. Mum and Dad'. I thank them very much. Next year I will celebrate the twentieth anniversary of my first parliamentary election victory. In 1976 I was branded a oncer. In 1977 my electoral defeat was universally predicted. In 1980 I was confronted by the toughest opponent the ALP put into the field for the House of Representatives in the entire Federal election-the Honourable Ken Wriedt.
—The big white hope.

—That is right, the big white hope. Ken Wriedt was Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and was said to be the best Minister in the dismissed, disgraced and discredited Whitlam Government. I do not overlook the fact that the present Prime Minister, the honourable member for Wills, was also a candidate in that 1980 Federal election. Last year, with the new and incredible-I repeat, `incredible'-electoral boundaries for Denison, members of the media said with confidence: `This time Hodgman will certainly go to the gallows'. As my record proves, I am a survivor. Like those well known T-shirts which proclaim `I don't get angry, I just get even', my motto should be more appropriately `I don't get upset, I just get more determined'.

SPEECH.PARA: So there it is. Without rancour or emotion I have got off my chest what I felt I must say. I turn now to two fundamental matters which I believe are absolutely critical for the future of Australia. The first is the destruction and defeat-the total annihilation-of the Hawke socialist Government and the second, which is its natural corollary, is the election of a coalition Liberal-National Party government at the earliest possible opportunity. Madam Deputy Speaker, Australia is bankrupt. Putting it bluntly, Australia is broke. The economic vandals who constitute the Hawke socialist Government have created a situation in which Australia's overseas debt has doubled in less than two years. The so-called world's greatest Treasurer-the man to whom, Hansard will show, I referred once as `the world's only two-faced ferret'-is shortly to find that his gold medal, awarded last year, will be repossessed. SPEECH.PARA: Before the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) leaves the chamber I want to make one comment about the composition of the Opposition front bench. I refer to the absence of women from the new front bench of the Opposition. One should understand why once again women have been excluded from the front bench. There is talent there but it is not recognised for one good reason-that the very dryness, the aridness of the Opposition in its shift to the far Right has no place for a woman. I will tell the House why. It is because the prehistoric, archaic economic policies that the Opposition wants to put forward in this chamber will hurt most the women of Australia. The Opposition wants to cut back the single parent benefit. It has gone on the airwaves and in print as saying that it would be one of the first welfare measures for the axe. It wants to cut back on child care. In fact when the Opposition was not so dry it cut back child care by half. What would it do in its full dryness, its full aridity? It wants to see women out of the work force because it considers they are taking places from young people and some men. It wants women back in the homes. There will be no choice. Is it any wonder that the women of Australia will not bear that? The women of the Liberal Party, even those of the Right, could not bear that sort of policy. It is a blight on the Opposition that it could not find a place on its front bench for a female member of its ranks. I predict not the demise of this Government, as did the honourable member for Denison, and not a cutback in our numbers or a turn in opposition; I predict that the Opposition will be the first to be rejected by the women of Australia because of its turn to the Right.

I wish mainly to speak today in support of the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1985-86, the Budget Bill. I dismiss the amendment that has been put forward by the Opposition, I suppose we still have the same amendment put forward by the honourable member for Kooyong. I suppose we are dealing with the same sort of economic policies. I have not seen any change to the Opposition amendment. It is predicted by the new Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) that things will be different, that the Opposition will have a harder look at government enterprises and that there will be a shift in its economic policies. Yet we are still left with the same amendment put forward earlier. We will have to give the Opposition some time to show its paces to see whether indeed it has changed from the Peacock led Opposition to the Howard led Opposition.

The Budget is only one of the several measures which any responsible government, such as the Hawke Government, puts into operation. We do not rely on monetary economics. We are not Friedmanites. We do not control the economy simply by manipulating the money supply; we also employ budgetary economics. This Budget is continuing for the third successive year the most successful pathway to recovery that this country has seen since the deep recession of the 1930s and the late 1970s and early 1980s.

There is another plank which is a first for an Australian government's policies in this country. Added to the monetary policies, added to the budgetary policies, it is the first time that Australia has had an incomes policy, which is known affectionately on this side of the chamber as the accord. It is welcomed, understood and supported by and has received the co-operation of the trade union movement in this country. It is this triple approach-with the accord, correct monetary policies and tight budgetary policies-which has turned the economy around from the disasters of a few years ago under the Howard treasuryship and under the Fraser Government.

Let us look at a few economic indicators of that successful turnaround of the economy, putting it on the right road to economic revival. Take the case of employment. In the last Fraser-Howard Budget year that Government lost 160,000 people from the work force; 160,000 jobs were lost. Yet in two and a half years this Government has created 410,000 jobs, which is 160,000 a year. It is a complete reversal of the disasters of a few years ago. Unemployment rose to 10.4 per cent. One in 10 people in the work force was out of a job. The figure has now dropped to 8.2 per cent. We do not think that is good enough but at least we have reduced it by that much. Now only one person in 12 is out of a job. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development predicts that in the next financial year we will be even more successful and will drive the figure down to 7.2 per cent, which is even better. That represents one person in every 13 out of a job.

With regard to inflation, which is another reliable economic indicator, we have almost halved the chronic high level of inflation, which under the last year of the Fraser-Howard Administration stood at over 11 per cent. It is now down to almost half that figure at 6.5 per cent. If we look at the deficit and how much money we spent, as was asked earlier by the Opposition member at the table, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), we can see who spent the money and who owed the money. Who was going to put the Government into debt? It was none other than your current leader, the honourable member for Bennelong and the then Treasurer, who in the last week of the election campaign was honest enough to admit to his Leader and the people that the Budget deficit had blown out in excess of $9 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a lie.

—If the honourable member for O'Connor checks the facts, he will see that it was at 5 per cent; one-twentieth of the gross domestic product at the time. Yet under this Government's successful policies we see that it has declined to 2.1 per cent of the gross domestic product; under $5 billion. One lesson which the Opposition has never learned is that the Government can use the deficit and government spending to create growth and employment. As that happens and the economy grows successfully, as it has done under this Government, so the deficit shrinks and the deficit as a percentage of GDP shrinks. The Opposition has never learned that. The Opposition thought that if it could cut back on government expenditure and make smaller government, somehow some miracle would occur under this dryness and aridity of economic understanding and there would be growth in the economy. That never happened. Year after year the economy shrank; it went backwards. The Budget deficit grew, yet the Opposition still did not understand that Australia has a mixed economy which needs co-operation and understanding between the public and private sectors; they both need each other. This Government knows that.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has wound back the Budget deficit-something the Opposition could never do-and at the same time has created growth. In doing so, it has used government spending in the first instance as a catalyst to accelerate growth. In no time at all, because of that reversal from deflationary economics to expansionary economics, growth has taken place in the private sector as well. Whereas last financial year one-third of the growth was in the public sector, this financial year public sector growth will decline to one-sixth, and 70 per cent of the total growth will take place in the private sector. For sustained economic recovery there needs to be an understanding of the mixed economy. In no way will Thatcherism, Reagonomics and Australia's new dryness and aridity ever come to grips with that. If the Opposition by some tragic mistake or miscalculation of the electors, ever got back to this side of the chamber we would be headed back to the dry, barren, shrinking years of the Fraser-Howard Government.

Fortunately, this Government has got the recovery going so well that it can now start responsibly to increase the standard of living for all Australians. We are doing that through our incomes policy-the accord-and also through a pattern of government expenditure. Where the money is spent is as important as how much is spent. We do not want to spend money on unemployment benefits or the welfare of the rich; we want people on unemployment benefits to be back in jobs, to have a choice of jobs and to earn their own income. We want the welfare needs of the poorest people to be met first. They are the big consumers in our society, the ones who turn over the money and, through the multiplier effect, get further growth into this economy. The pattern of government expenditure is as important as the level itself.

This Budget has done a remarkable thing. As I mentioned earlier, if government spending grows less quickly than the growth in GDP-one of the planks of the trilogy announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-then there is not a percentage increase in government expenditure, something which the Opposition still does not understand. Whilst this Budget has maintained real spending for important social programs, it has reduced government spending by a whole one percentage point, from 30.8 per cent of GDP down to 29.8 per cent. Also, this is the lowest increase in government spending for six years, including the last few years of the Howard-Treasurer, Fraser-Prime Minister Government.

The essential services provided by government include health, education, social security, community services and housing. Let us look at what happened in the years up to 1983 in this group of essential services, which is known throughout the union movement and by those who understand economics as the social wage. The understanding and agreement in the accord is that the Government will increase the social wage-social security, welfare and education and the infrastructure of the quality of life-for all Australians, provided that the trade union movement maintains its members standard of living not in excess of the growth in inflation or the increase in the cost of living. We have managed to do both things. The people in the trade union movement who are employed have maintained their standard of living. The Opposition wanted to cut back that standard. At the same time, we have been able to increase the social standard of living for all Australians. Yet in the years up to 1983 the Opposition, then in government, cut back unemployment benefits, halved child care facilities and slashed the real expenditure on health and public schools. It cut real government spending on these essential programs by 10 per cent in real terms over seven years. In other words, the social wage, that component of the standard of living provided by government, in 1983 was only 90 per cent of what it was when the Opposition took over government at the end of 1975.

I conclude by saying that the important message I had today was to show the Opposition that its aridity and dryness of economic policies will fall hardest on women in this community. No wonder there are no women on the front bench of that Opposition. Secondly, its idea of cutting back government expenditure in a mixed economy like Australia is out of place and destructive. The Opposition will follow that course again if it ever should get back on to this bench. I thoroughly support this Budget. I endorse the negotiations that have taken place between the trade union movement and this Government on strengthening the accord and I totally reject the sterile, dry amendments that have come from the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The thrust of the Budgets over recent years has concerned me very greatly. I see no change in the general direction of the Budget that we are now debating before the Parliament. I see no hope of looking into the future and saying that we as a country will overcome the great economic problems that confront us now. The Budget is a typical socialist, big spending Budget. We must remember always that if a government intends to spend, it must tax accordingly. It is of interest to note that in 1984-85 the revenue was $52.4 billion and for 1985-86 it will be $58.6 billion; an increase of 12 per cent over the year before. It is of interest to note also that the pay as your earn taxpayer, who is paid for his or her work in the community, will pay an extra 13 per cent in tax as a result of this present Labor Budget. Over the last two years the PAYE person has paid an extra 29 per cent in tax. This high taxation is alarming, and it is even more alarming when we realise that an extra 750,000 Australians will go into higher tax brackets this year. Of those 750,000, two-thirds will move from the 30c bracket to the 46c bracket and 250,000 will move from the 46c bracket up to the 60c bracket. I wonder whether the average Australian today realises just how high taxation is and what extra taxes will be paid not only by the PAYE person but also every one of those 4 1/2 million people paying tax in Australia. I can recall that years ago the morning after the Budget one looked for the extra tax on cigarettes, fuel and liquor. Let us not forget that the first action ever taken by this Government after it came to power in 1983 was to index the tax on those three important items. In other words, twice a year they will increase anyway. They are not included in the Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: We are looking now at the important issue of PAYE tax and other taxes, including taxes on essential commodities, that are facing the people of Australia. I believe that the people are very concerned. I do not want to be a pessimist but as I go around my electorate and elsewhere it strikes me that many people are concerned as to the way Australia is heading, not only from an economic point of view but also, for example, from a moral point of view. A great challenge faces Australians, and that challenge applies also to those of us in government and in opposition in this Parliament. We must be practical and constructive in regard to the issues and our policies in order to make this land of ours a better country than it is. Australia, as a country, appears to me at the moment to be like a farmer who does not store hay or silage on his farm for a drought. We do not have the reserves to meet the challenges that we have, to keep our own economy and standards where they are, or to supply to a world that is hungry the products we produce on our farms and in the manufacturing sector. In other words, I believe that we as a people have lived beyond our means. Over the last 15 years at least, since the deterioration set in with the Whitlam Administration when innovations were enacted in this Parliament and in the States with the concurrence and support of the Commonwealth, the country has been dragged down. We need to realise that 5 1/2 million Australians are living with government support and only 4 1/4 million taxpayers in Australia are supporting those people. I read, as I am sure every member of this Parliament read, every word that John Leard recently published in every major paper in Australia. I have not seen one person of authority contradict him. That is the important issue. I have not seen the Treasurer (Mr Keating) come out in print and say `No, we don't believe in those principles and those issues that John Leard laid down'. Every member of this House should heed the advice given. When we are looking at the future we should know that his concern is shared by many, if not millions, of Australian people who are worried about the future of this great land of ours.

TALK.START.PARA: —He wasted $70,000 on nonsense.

—And he woke up a lot of people in this country. I hope he woke up the Government, but I do not think it has heeded one thing he said. I am not the only one in Parliament to cite the figures to which I am about to refer, but they should be cited over and over again. The more we realise and the average Australian appreciates this problem the quicker we might get back on the rails and see the real problems and challenges that Australia has. Australia has a foreign debt of $70 billion. That debt has gone up in 15 years from $3.5 billion to $70 billion. Interest charges on that debt amount to almost $10 billion a year, and that amounts to a $15,000 debt for every family and an $8,000 debt for every person employed in Australia. Is that not cause for alarm? Should not we as a Parliament be alarmed when the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development says that over a period of 50 years Australia has gone from second on the list of wealthy countries to 21st? Are we not concerned that our inflation rate of 10 per cent is double that of any Western country which sells against us on the markets of the world? Should we not be concerned about that? Should we not be concerned about a government that in this Budget will spend 15 per cent above the amount that it collects? In other words, it will raise moneys to meet its indebtedness. The Treasurer has referred to an upturn in Australia's economy. I do not know where it is; it is not in my electorate.
—It is not in mine, either.

—My colleagues confirm that it is not in their electorates. The other day an ordinary working man said to me: `Today I paid 20 per cent more for groceries that I purchased at the store than I paid six months ago'. I wonder how the consumer price index is worked out. The National Farmers Federation in a submission to the Government said that some essential items of plant and farm costs have gone up by 40 per cent over a two-year period. Is it not reasonable that we should be concerned? If the Treasurer can talk up Australia's economy, if he can say that the CPI, inflation and interest rates are staying down-which he cannot-that is simply because it is a false economy being propped up by the borrowings of this nation, by the borrowings and spending of this big government.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the unemployment figures. How many people are employed under the community employment program? Possibly 60,000 people. They are not on the unemployment list. If we add them to the list we go well beyond the 8 per cent unemployment figure; it would be up around 10 per cent. The Government cannot quarrel with that. I say to the Government that it must look at realities to see where this country really stands. We are being judged by the world. Even after the Budget the value of our dollar has been down; it was down to 66c on the American market yesterday. Other countries can judge us better than we can judge ourselves.

I would not be very happy if I were a Treasurer bringing a Budget into the Parliament with the national debt that we have, with the low dollar that we have, with the high interest rates that we have and with the inflation and unemployment that we have. Are they not reasons enough for a member to get up in this House, as I am doing now, and warn this country that we are in serious financial difficulties? The sooner we face up to the problems that we have the better because high taxation will ruin the incentive of any person. It is ruining the incentive of most of our pay as you earn wage earners today. It is killing their incentive and it is killing the incentive of small business, of farmers and surely of bigger business throughout Australia. I know that we need a reformation of our taxation system, and the Government was going to tackle that. The Treasurer was keen. He and the Prime Minister decided they would have a summit. I will not go over that again; it has been talked about before. But not one Australian will forget what was said and what was done in the discussions with industry, farmers organisations and different groups within the community.

What are we faced with now, besides our high taxation? On Thursday week the Treasurer will come in here and give us a present for the spring. He will give us a present of a capital gains tax and a tax on fringe benefits. Goodness knows what else the Australian people will suffer. Has anyone in this country asked for a capital gains tax? Of course they have not. Has primary industry asked for a capital gains tax? Of course it has not. No group in this country has asked for it; only members of the socialist left who sit opposite us have asked for it. They are the ones who day after day come into the Parliament and go out into the country asking for a capital gains tax-a movement of wealth within the community. Their attitude is: `Get the money from where it is and give it to the people who need it'. This country was never as prosperous as it was when we had a Liberal-National Party coalition government. Just look what has happened since. If anything ever kills the working people of this country it will be a Labor government. Everything that this Government does pulls this country down.

Why does the Labor Government continually hit the people who put it into power? I think the people of this country are starting to wake up. They will not tolerate this Government any longer. They will not tolerate it because it is being controlled by an unelected party-the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Today the Treasurer at Question Time talked about a wonderful achievement-the Government has made a written agreement with the ACTU, an unelected body. What would happen if a Liberal-National Party government had a written arrangement with some group within Australia? A government must be independent. If one looks at the aims of the ACTU one sees that it is militant. I am not talking about the average unionist who has a lot of common sense. After all, 30 per cent of them vote for us anyway, so we are told.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, 40 per cent.

—Well, 40 per cent; that is even better. If the ACTU is ever successful in placing a capital gains tax upon the heads of Australians, we must then consider what this will mean to the incentive of Australians. How about the person who wants to rent a home? How about the young person in the community who wants to build a home? If I were a trained builder or carpenter I would scratch to buy a block of land and build a home. Suppose I put it on the market, sold it and then did the same again. Honourable members opposite will say that one will not pay capital gains tax on the first home. That may be so, but what about after that? What about the person who wants to build three or four homes to provide housing within the community, to own his or her own home? Is owning a home not the aim of any ordinary Australian? What about the person on a low income who wants to obtain rental accommodation? The States have failed to supply such accommodation. There are more than 50,000 people on the Housing Commission list in New South Wales. They are not being housed. What does the Government think of this? If it does not give incentives to people to build homes and provide accommodation, how can the average Australian get rental property at a reasonable price?

SPEECH.PARA: We need to look at Australia very carefully. We have all been responsible for a deterioration in our productivity in every field, except primary industry. In that area productivity has increased at the rate of 2 per cent a year. What an opportunity we have as Australians. The Government is now supporting the unions, so we are told, on a 38-hour week in industry overall. Just look at this country: Four weeks annual leave with a 17 1/2 per cent loading, a five-day working week from Monday to Friday only. Let us look at these issues. In light of the hours our competitors, the Japanese, work can we compete on the technology and other markets of the world? The Japanese work 48 hours per week. Other countries work many more hours than we do. How long can we afford to continue like this? The Government of this country should propose a referendum of the Australian people asking them if they want to return to what would be acceptable working hours and conditions in industry in Australia. I suggest that that referendum be held in the same manner as the Swiss held their referendum. When the Swiss Government went to the people it suggested what they should vote on; it set out the conditions of employment in the community. This is what this country needs to get us out of the mire. All the Budgets, all the lower taxation proposals, all the things that the Government wants to bring in will not cure the ills that are facing Australia at present. Why should our young people be deprived of work? Why should hundreds of thousands of people who want to work be out of work? This Government sides with the unions all the time. What this country needs is another wages pause. We should forget indexation because this country needs at least one year of a wages pause and it is a pity that there cannot be a prices pause as well to enable us to compete with the rest of the world and put ourselves on an equal footing with other countries. I do not like the accord; I have never liked it. It is a strangulation. It is an agreement between the Government and the unions, an agreement that can never work, one that deprives people of jobs, boosts inflationary trends and puts up interest rates.

I turn to primary industry. We must realise the problems facing primary industry in Australia. A farmer came to my electoral office the other day and told me that he was paying 19 1/2 per cent on a debt of above $100,000 on a reasonably small dairy farm. We must all wake up. How can anybody, particularly a farmer whose average net income this year is only $6,500, afford an interest rate as high as that? He just cannot afford this. What we must do is say to the primary producers-as we, in the National Party, have always done-`We are sympathetic to the problems you have, we want to bring the economy back, we want to get people back to work, we want to make Australia competitive in world markets and we have to keep our costs down'. That is the only way that primary industry and the farmer can survive in Australia. I see no reason why the Government should not encourage farmers to form their own bank. I know that interest rates are high at the moment, but the interest bearing deposits were abolished by the Government-one source of finance that could go into such a fund. When the money markets return to normal and interest rates are reasonably low, farmers could borrow from this bank over a term of years. The bank could take people's investments and be backed by a guarantee of the Government. Thus funding could be provided for the settlement of people on the land and for continuing finance for expanding activities on farms. My time is up but there are a lot of things I would like to say. I have dwelt this evening on my grave concern about the way this country is going, and I believe we have a duty to take it seriously--
