Let us not forget that. I do not think the community will forget it.

SPEECH.PARA: Some honourable members opposite are scrabbling around for some overarching philosophy that will give them a cloak of respectability. One of the interesting things said of perpetrators of dogma is that they shout the same thing over and over again. We are seeing that already from Opposition members. It is shouted so loudly that they silence the voice of reason in their own heads. Opposition members are starting to shout the word `privatisation' over and over again so as to silence the voice of reason within themselves. They are developing a very spurious sort of view. It is as if we were trying to develop a science of meteorology based on the fluttering of flags. It is so inconsistent, so absolutely casual. There is no theoretical base to it. It is just a question of grabbing a few cliches and putting them together.

There is no overarching philosophy with privatisation because honourable members opposite do not know to which god they will bow. Is it the god of Thatcherism? Is it the god of the National Party? They are not really sure? The Australian community is not sure either, and people will remain uncertain because the Opposition's factions will continue to have that degree of uncertainty.

Nevertheless, we on this side of the House will press on because we have some things to say about unemployment and about the creation of jobs. There have been 410,000 new jobs created in the first two and a half years of the Hawke Governments. Unemployment has fallen from 10.4 per cent to 8.2 per cent. I was puzzled recently when I visited a community employment program project and the manager said: `One of the problems that we are having here is that every time new people start on the job, very quickly someone from the private sector comes along and finds them a job'. The brickie's labourers, builder's labourers, general building labourers and bricklayers are continually being snatched up by the private sector, which has so much demand for them.

Clearly, Opposition members need to recognise that when we talk about job creation we are talking about substantial job creation. Statistically, it is happening; but we can report about it anecdotally, as I have just done. We must recognise it. It is something that all the shouting and dogmatic repetition from the Opposition will not remove from the scene. The facts are that jobs have been created and unemployment has been reduced, as has inflation. We talk about the reduction of inflation as being an important goal of this Government. It was a goal of the previous Government but, sadly, that Government missed it. What it did was to produce a massive recession, and it missed the target. It had double-digit inflation and double-digit unemployment. It was not a happy spectacle. The new Leader of the Opposition must recognise that he was responsible for it in large part. The community will not forget that. Neither shall we on this side of the House allow the Opposition or the community to forget it. The guru Stone and the born again Leader of the Opposition cannot be forgotten. The circumstances when the latter was Treasurer were very grim. They were the grim years. That is something that we ought to remember.

We are looking again at a situation of improved economic growth. One of the problems of the ill thought out positions that have been sent to us from honourable members opposite is that they somehow have a view that if one can just bear down on the economy and pull it down one will not only reduce inflation but also somehow reduce interest rates and wage pressure-forgetting that in our economy there is a linkage between the private sector and the public sector, and a linkage in regard to the expectations of the community, of investors in particular but certainly of consumers and wage earners, about what tomorrow will bring. If one continues to talk doom and gloom, which is what we have had from the Opposition-certainly the experience in government of honourable members opposite convinces us that all they can produce is doom and gloom-logically what one gets is a reduced economic performance. That was the experience, and it has not been the experience since we came to office.

There is a linkage. We are prepared to acknowledge that the Australian union movement is a mature part of the economy and is a group of people whom we believe should be spoken to as if they play a role and not as people to be kicked around simply because one has an ideological urge to seek out victims. Clearly, the experience of the Opposition when in government is that honourable members opposite are very strong on victimisation of anyone who is underprivileged or who is without power. The union movement is a group that they also seek to victimise repetitively. They forget that that movement is made up of rank and file members who are mature responsible citizens who do not like being kicked around; they do not like the newly found dries of the Opposition kicking them around.

It is a very unproductive view of the world and one that we do not share. Our record shows that by rejecting it, we are able to put scores on the board. We have recently had the accord being re-endorsed and redeveloped for the next two years. That means for employers and wage earners that there is a degree of certainty, and there is also a reduction in industrial disputation. That must be recognised. That has been our experience in terms of what we have done. It has been our experience, as a government, in getting the economy going. We have reduced industrial disputes, reduced inflation, and increased employment. Clearly, the performance is there to be seen.

I wish to comment on the Opposition's fetish of privatisation and deregulation. There is pressure from the Opposition. Opposition members are supporting some of the views of bodies such as the Real Estate Institute of Australia in regard to deregulating housing interest rates. Recent research that we have had undertaken suggests that there will be a 2 1/4 per cent increase in housing interest rates if they are deregulated. Looking at the performance in the overdraft market, one finds that clearly there have been pressures towards increases in rates, and they have shown up on the market. If we were to deregulate housing interest rates, we would see an increase of about 2 1/4 per cent. That would not be tolerable. If the Opposition continues to press the notion of deregulation of housing interest rates, we shall see people paying a very heavy price. Advice has also been given to people in the community that if housing interest rates go up they should increase their repayment period. I strongly reject that advice. I also reject the deregulation of housing interest rates and strongly endorse what the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said about that. Take the repayment schedules of people trying to keep their repayments steady but at the same time trying to absorb the impact of increases in interest rates. With a 25 year mortgage, which is a fairly common mortgage base in Australia, the rise from 13.5 per cent interest to 14 per cent-which is a fairly small increase given the 2 1/4 per cent increase those seeking deregulation want-would increase the repayment term to 45 years if monthly repayments were not increased. Clearly the message to the Australian community is that in the face of any movement in housing interest rates the goal ought to be to maintain the period of the mortgage rather than to increase it. If the period is increased that simply increases people's indebtedness over a very long period.

The Australian community needs to recognise and to understand that behind all this rhetoric about deregulation and privatisation the sober reality of the deregulation of housing interest rates is that it would result, on current estimates provided to me in the joint government-industry housing committee that meets in Perth-with people from the Master Builders Association, the Housing Industry Association, financial institutions and the State Minister, Keith Wilson-in an increase of 2 1/4 per cent. If we were to apply that to the housing sector-this is where I think the Opposition has to face up to the reality of its rhetoric as we saw what happened during those five grim Howard years-we would see the Australian community facing an intolerable burden with an increase of 2 1/4 per cent in interest rates. That is not acceptable. I conclude this section by saying that we have to be clear when we say to people in the Australian community that if they are faced with an increase in housing interest rates they must not increase the repayment period as that would increase their indebtedness enormously. The message is very clear in that respect. The message is also clear that those in the Opposition must not only talk about privatisation and deregulation but begin to apply it.

We saw the result of the Opposition's ill thought out philosophy when it was in government It dragged the economy into severe recession. It produced a national crisis in terms of direction, growth and performance. We are not prepared to do that or to see that ill thought out philosophy being applied. Government is about partnerships-between governments, business and the union movement. Those partnerships should develop in a mature way. Since March 1983 we have done very well in terms of statistics and attitudes. This is a better country to live in. Scapegoating is now not on. The sorts of mentalities that were the order of the day under the now discredited Opposition, which sought out victims, are not on any more. We try to treat people in the Australian community as mature partners. The record is there statistically and in terms of the expectations that are framed in this Budget. It is clearly a case of the Australian community being able to discern the difference between a government which has thought out its policies, applied them and got results and an Opposition that, as I began by saying, has a philosophy of privatisation that is about as scientific as meteorology would be if it were to study the fluttering of flags.

I believe we have a lot more to offer this economy and this society than those vague rhetorical positions we are seeing from the Opposition. The score is on the board and the projected future is in the Budget. I am accordingly pleased to commend the Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is well known that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has a gift for coining memorable metaphors and phrases. We all remember his famous metaphorical tax reform cart in which he toured the country, with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the cart one day and not in it the next, and the Australian Council of Trade Unions which was maybe going to be in it and finally was not in it, until it was scuttled. I remember another of his phrases of what he thought about the Australian Broadcasting Commission. He said that it is not worth another zack. We remember what he thinks of `the basket weavers of Balmain'-another one of his famous phrases-and so on. Characteristically the Treasurer had a phrase to describe that legion of responsible observers who are less than enthusiastic about the 1985 Budget, who look behind the sort of economic growth which the Treasurer so proudly proclaims to the forces that are fuelling it in Australia, although not in most of the rest of the world. These critics see the growth all right, but they believe that too much of it is the wrong sort of growth. It is growth dependent on high taxation, loose money, high interest rates and high inflation. True, it is growth, but it is associated with low investment despite there being plenty of money about. It is an ill based growth which will soon undermine the real growth that is part of the world economic turn-up.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer quickly had a phrase for these critics, the people who took this line on the Budget. He described them as `bankers and basket weavers on a low growth unity ticket'. These bankers and basket weavers, as he calls them, are of course those businessmen, commentators and journalists who are worried about accelerated inflationary growth. They are supported in any case by the cautious warning from the Treasury advisers, given on page 62 of Budget Paper No. 1, where they say that if inflation is not controlled:
. . . the macroeconomic outlook would become progressively less favourable as 1986 unfolds.
Page 76 of the Paper also says:
Any ratcheting up of the inflation rate could have important adverse effects on the economy, harming confidence and prospects for continued growth as 1986 proceeds.

The point is that these fears are being realised yet all the Treasurer can do when attention is called to them is to describe the critics, the people who make the observation, as a unity ticket of bankers and basket weavers.

Let us be clear on one thing: Everyone agrees that genuine growth, real investment and technological innovation are essential if Australia is not to continue its slide downwards in the tables which give international comparisons of the standards of living of various countries. One hundred years ago we had the world's highest standard of living. That is not an Australian boast as it is acknowledged in all of these tables. Today many countries-Switzerland, the United States of America, Norway, Sweden, Canada, Denmark and West Germany-have higher standards of living than we do. Japan's standard of living will soon overtake ours and soon Singapore's will also. All this is well known. I am not bringing news to the House when I refer to these facts. They are well known and agreed upon. Professor Helen Hughes put it well recently when she said that on current trends bright young Australians will soon be seeking scholarships and professional employment in Singapore, and low-skilled Australians will be seeking jobs in other rapidly growing Asian countries. This is not just rhetoric but a serious possibility. Even on some elementary social indicators, such as simple life expectancy at birth-Australians have always been so proud of their physical expectations-we find many countries such as Canada, the United States, Sweden, Switzerland, France and Japan, have better records than Australia. Similar figures, unhappily, apply in the field of infant mortality. The point is that in many respects we have ceased to be a country of enterprise, innovation and expansion.

It is also agreed that real growth in Australia is needed to reverse these and other damaging trends. To achieve this real growth will require a variety of policies ranging from education policies, which concentrate on achievement and not on Mickey Mouse courses, to trade policies encouraging international competitiveness and industrial policies reducing the nationally suicidal policies of trade union commissars. Of course, everyone wants growth, but not the short term inflationary growth resulting from policies that bring future and near future disaster. This is what the Hawke Government is doing. The Treasurer, by thinking and repeatedly talking about growth in this House, confusing real growth and inflationary growth, confusing investment growth and consumption growth, is deceiving the Australian people. Where we do have real growth, this Government and the Treasurer have done nothing to create it and, in fact, through their policies they are doing everything to undermine it.

I turn now to the Government's policies and I shall take its high tax policies first. There were no tax cuts in the Budget. Whatever cuts may be announced later, along with new taxes, we see on page 331 of Budget Paper No. 1 that net pay as you earn tax has been increased by 13.3 per cent. Allowing for inflation of 8 per cent, that means a 5.3 per cent increase in real terms in PAYE tax imposed by this Government in the Budget. In Labor's three Budgets in 1983-84, 1984-85 and 1985-86, we find a real increase in PAYE taxation of 11.7 per cent. The figures given by the Treasury in the Budget Papers show an 11.7 increase in PAYE tax in just three Budgets. This figure is reached by taking the nominal increases in Budget receipts, which are given on page 441 of Budget Paper No. 1, and deducting from those nominal increases the consumer price increases, which are given on page 33. The nominal increase in receipts since the last coalition Budget, when they were $18,840m, and the estimate for 1985-86, which is $25,390m, is 35 per cent. The CPI increase for the first Labor Budget was 7.9 per cent. For the second Budget, it was 5.8 per cent, and the estimate for this Budget is 8 per cent-a total of 23.3 per cent. By deducting the CPI increase of 23.3 per cent from the nominal increase of 35 per cent we get a real increase of PAYE tax of 11.7 per cent. This figure does not include the Medicare levy.

It is ridiculous for the Treasurer to talk about restraining taxes when, on his own figures, he has presided over this 11.7 per cent real and not nominal increase in PAYE tax. This Budget year will see 750,000 taxpayers move into a higher tax bracket, with about 570,000 moving into the 47c in the dollar tax bracket for those earnings over $19,500 a year. Incidentally, in the United States of America one does not begin to pay that sort of tax until one is earning around $A150,000 a year. In Australia one starts to pay 47c in the dollar in tax when one is earning $19,500 a year. No wonder our tax system is one of the wonders of the world and is a crippling disincentive which this Budget makes worse. To be fair, I have to acknowledge that the Treasurer tried to do something about this with his famous but ill-fated tax cart, but the Prime Minister did not have the stomach for the struggle with the ACTU that such a reform would have involved, and the Prime Minister made that famous motel deal behind the Treasurer's back, and that was the end of the cart.

In any case, we know that Labor governments believe in high taxes, whatever this Government may sometimes hypocritically say. The present Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) has not withdrawn a statement he made as spokesman on the economy when he said:
I'm a high tax man.

He has not withdrawn his statement that democratic socialism, which he espouses as opposed to social democracy, is against what he called the `deeply dispiriting doctrine' of lower tax and smaller government. The former Leader of the Australian Labor Party finds the idea of lower taxes and smaller government a deeply dispiriting doctrine. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) has not withdrawn his statement that the electorate should be pleased to pay higher taxes to build up the public sector and that tax should be used, for example, to reduce the profitability of banks. One could go on. Although these things are well known, it pays to spell them out.

Another way of spelling things out is to compare the annual increase in total taxation under the Hawke Government-as opposed to PAYE taxation which I have just been dealing with-with the annual increase in the Fraser Government's seven Budgets. I shall draw on the figures in the Budget Papers tabled by the Treasurer. Page 411 of Budget Paper No. 1 shows that between 1975-76 and 1982-83 nominal total tax increased about 2 1/4 times. Using one's calculator that is an exact increase of 2.245 times. It is a nominal increase from $16,807m to $40,765m. In those same years the consumer price index went from 67.3 to 134.7. The CPI doubled or, if one wants to use one's calculator, it increased 2.001 times. The increase in nominal tax was 21 per cent greater than the increase in the CPI. So under the coalition the rate of increase in real taxes in each year over the seven years averaged out at 2 3/4 per cent. That is an increase in total taxes which nobody welcomed, but Labor has doubled it.

In the first three Keating Budgets real total tax increased each year by 5 1/2 per cent as against the 2 3/4 per cent rate of increase under the coalition's seven Budgets. The nominal taxes from the $40.765m of 1982-83 to the $58,627m of 1985-86 increased 1.438 times. In the same three years the CPI increased from 134.7 in 1982-83 to 165.9 in 1985-86, an increase of 1.23 times. That is a percentage in real taxes of 16.7 per cent or about 5.2 per cent a year. That is almost double the rate increase under the Fraser Government. Whether we are looking at PAYE tax or total taxes, on the figures given in the Budget Papers by the Treasurer this Government is very much a high taxing government and is a far higher taxing government than was the coalition Government.

I have not mentioned the hidden tax increases in the Budget. The tax on petrol, spirits, beer and cigarettes now rises twice yearly in February and August, in accordance with CPI movements, without the Treasurer ever having to mention it. Anybody buying such items in the last few days would have noticed the increased taxes, although the Treasurer did not have to say a word about them in the Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —He said he didn't increase them.

—He did not even mention them. He did not have to increase them in the sense that they increased without his having to do so. He had already arranged for them to be increased twice a year in accordance with the CPI movements. I have not dealt with those taxes nor have I dealt with the new taxes on capital gains and fringe benefits which are to be announced shortly, but I think that I have said enough to illustrate the high tax policy of this Government. This policy is essential to the Government's whole strategy of big spending. The Government has the idea that if it is a big spender and if the public is spending money and since there will be economic growth of a badly based kind, all our problems will be solved. The fact is that we are getting high inflation, high interest rates and low investment.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —In discussing this Budget, let us turn now from taxes to money growth. There can be no doubt about the looseness of money in Australia under this Government. Table 17 on page 44 of Budget Paper No. 1 sets out the basic facts. Between the June 1983 quarter and the June 1985 quarter the money base-roughly cash-moved from 6.3 to 14.9; the M3 from 11.8 to 15.9 and broad money, including that of building societies and finance companies, from 11.2 to 15.4 The September issue of the London Economist, which the Government sometimes likes to quote, shows that Australia has the highest rate of money growth of the 12 largest economies of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. Australia's rate of money growth is given as 18.7 per cent against, for example, Canada's 4.8 per cent, West Germany's 5 per cent and Sweden's 2.7 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: A Press release by the Reserve Bank of Australia of 26 August gives the Australian rate of money growth as 19.6 per cent. That was, no doubt, an atypical month. However, the annual rate is still 15 to 16 per cent. If we allow four per cent for real growth and one per cent for a decline in velocity, it still indicates an inflation rate of 10 to 11 per cent in the near future. We are rapidly getting back to the Whitlam levels of inflation. The capitulation by the Government the other day to the Australian Council of Trade Unions and its failure to discount the 3.8 consumer price index rise by 0.8 per cent for devaluation will push it along more quickly.

The prospect for the immediate future is not so bad. The Budget forecasts that inflation will move from 5.8 per cent to 8 per cent in 1985-86. However, by international comparisons, this is a very bad rate even for the immediate future. The Reserve Bank bulletin for July 1985 gives OECD forecasts for inflation. For West Germany the inflation rate is 2.25 per cent; for Japan 2.5 per cent and for the United States 3.5 per cent. So our 8 per cent rate is far higher-in some cases more than three times higher-than that of our competitors. As I say, the rate of money growth indicates a coming inflation rate far worse than the current 8 per cent in the not too distant future.

The same pattern emerges with interest rates. Page 86 of the Economist of 6 September provides international comparisons. Australia's overdraft rate is given as 17.75, compared with 5.5 for Japan, 7.5 for both West Germany and Switzerland and 9.5 for the United States. Deducting the inflation rates in each case, as given on page 85 of the Economist, to get the real rates, Australia's overdraft rate remains the highest, at 11.05, as against Japan's 3.2, West Germany's 5.2, Switzerland's 4.1 and the United States' 5.8.

The Treasurer has his economic growth all right, but at the price of high taxation, high inflation and high interest rates. One consequence is low rates of investment, as the Budget Papers show. On page 7 of Budget Paper No. 10 we see that between 1982-83 and 1984-85, when real gross domestic product rose by 10 per cent, real private investment rose by a miserable one per cent. Page 19 of Budget Paper No. 1 shows that investment in private equipment, machinery, et cetera, in 1984-85 as a proportion of gross domestic product was the lowest in 10 years.

There are other figures. Table 6 on page 10 of Budget Paper No. 10 shows that investments in dwellings, non-dwelling constructions and equipment are all below the levels of 1980-81 or 1981-82. It is a pity that the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) is not in the chamber. There was, it is true, an increase in investment in dwellings between 1982-83 and 1984-85, although it did not reach the levels of 1980-81 or 1981-82. At the same time, between 1982-83 and 1984-85, investment in non-dwelling construction and equipment fell.

There is plenty of money in the community. It has to go somewhere. It is not going into investment, so it is going into consumption. We have economic growth, of which the Treasurer boasts, but it is based on loose money and consumption with high taxation, high inflation, high interest rates and low investment. This is the Budget of a rudderless government which cannot confront the real problems of Australia even when it sees them. The National Taxation Summit fiasco is a lasting symbol of this Government. It meant well. It wanted to restructure the tax system. However it dared not proceed against the ukase of the ACTU. This Government cannot deal with the problems of big government, excessive regulation, youth unemployment, labour market rigidities, welfare rackets, educational decline and low investment. So it opts for short term inflationary growth and plays at rearranging the chairs on the Titanic.
The Hawke Government is very similar to the Whitlam Government in opposite circumstances. The Whitlam Government experienced the inevitable effects on Australia of a world recession.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1985-86 Federal Budget has been very well received by everyone. The Budget deficit has been cut from $6.7 billion in 1984-85 to $4.9 billion in 1985-86. This means that in three Budgets the Hawke Government has halved the deficit as a share of the total economy. Federal Budget outlays will be in excess of $69 billion or, in this year, a 1.3 per cent increase in real terms. The Hawke Government has been more successful than any previous Australian Government in managing the Australian economy. On winning office in March 1983 the new Hawke Government was faced with a projected deficit of $9.6 billion, just one of the legacies of the previous Fraser Government. For most of the Fraser years the architect of that Government's economic policies was the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), the honourable member for Bennelong. What did the present Opposition Leader and former Treasurer in the Fraser Government leave behind him? He left behind him the worst recession for 50 years, the economy in tatters, industry in turmoil and inflation running in excess of 11 per cent. Unemployment had soared to over 10 per cent and, unfortunately, Australia was a divided nation.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also noteworthy that Australia should achieve economic growth in excess of 5 per cent this year. This is the third successive year under this Government that this important goal has been achieved. No real redistribution within the economy is readily available to governments without increasing the size of the cake through economic growth. In contrast, an economic growth rate of 5 per cent was not achieved in any of the seven unfortunate Fraser years. The Hawke Government can be very proud of its record. The deficit is down to $4.9 billion. Inflation has been halved, although we have just heard complaints from the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) about high inflation. I wonder what he thinks of the previous Government, of which he was a member just a few years ago. It seems an extraordinary contradiction to come from the honourable member, as do the bleatings of the Opposition.

Unemployment has been reduced from a peak of 10.4 per cent to 8.2 per cent. Under this Government, 410,000 new jobs have been created. We are well on the way to surpassing our promised half a million jobs in our first three years of government. In contrast, the Fraser-Howard team created 340,000 jobs in 7 1/2 years. The Hawke Government has also introduced Medicare, substantially lifted social security payments and benefits, increased spending on education, housing and home purchase assistance, achieved a higher real level of spending in defence and funded the community employment program. Transport and sport, just to name two other areas, have also received substantial increases in funding.

In 2 1/2 years we have achieved a great deal. However, as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said on Budget night, our task is far from complete. Two other Government decisions have also had and will continue to have a good and substantial effect on our economy: Firstly, the floating of the Australian dollar which, amongst other things, has had a beneficial effect on our export industries and in particular our manufacturing industries; and, secondly, the granting of 16 new banking licences. Our banking system will see a number of changes as these new banks enter the banking arena over the coming months. Some of he world's largest banks have been granted licences. A few will enter the system without local partners whilst others have entered into partnerships with large Australian companies and enterprises or State governments, as is the case in some instances. Both decisions that I have mentioned have had and will have far-reaching economic consequences for Australia. The Australian economy is becoming stronger every year as shown by the third successive year of economic growth in excess of 5 per cent. I repeat-it is worth repeating-that if there is to be a fundamental redistribution of the wealth in this country and a movement towards any type of equality within our society the cake must be expanded. It can only be expanded through the economic growth that this Government has achieved in three successive years. The Hawke Government has reversed the disastrous trends of the Fraser years and created a solid base for an efficient and effective Australian economy.

The three Budgets of the Hawke Government have been very much what I would call Labor Budgets with funds being directed to assist those who most need assistance. The total social security and welfare budgets in 1985-86 will exceed $19 billion, which amounts to 27.6 per cent of total Budget outlays. This is an increase of 6.9 per cent.

In addition to these outlays on social security and welfare, assistance is provided through the personal income tax system. It is therefore appropriate that I outline some of the outlays in this important area. The Government has again increased payments for low income families. For people on pensions or benefits the additional tax free payment for children will increase from $14 a week for each child to $16 a week from November this year. This increase means that, since the Government won office, it has lifted the additional pension or benefit for children by 60 per cent. The maximum rate of family income supplement will increase from $14 to $16 a week per child also from November this year. This new level of payment represents a 60 per cent increase since it was introduced in May 1983. From May 1986 the tax free mother's or guardian's allowance which is paid to sole parent pensioners or beneficiaries will increase by $2 a week to $12 per family. This payment will then be up to 100 per cent higher than it was before the election of the Hawke Government.

When added to indexation these increases result in significant improvements in assistance as shown in the following examples. A sole parent pensioner or beneficiary with two children on maximum rate payments will get an extra $7.60 per week from November 1985. From 1 May next year this increases to $9.60 extra plus a further indexation increase in the basic rate. A family with three children living on wages of less than $229 a week will receive $48 a week through the family income supplement.

The Budget again acts to close the gap between pensions and unemployment benefits for those aged 21 and over by providing for a special $3 increase over and above normal indexation. From November the new rate of this benefit of $91.45 a week will be $27 higher than it was in 1983. The Government has also acted to help the young unemployed by lifting all payments for 16- and 17-year-olds to $50 a week. The Budget also establishes an intermediate level of benefit for 18- to 20-year-olds without dependants. The level of benefit for this group will increase by $3 in November 1985 to $88.20 and it is intended that further increases will apply from January 1987 and January 1988 with subsequent indexation increases each year.

In addition this year's Budget contains two major initiatives to help meet the needs of the unemployed: Firstly, rent assistance of up to $10 a week and, secondly, an easing in the income test so that people can earn more before their benefit is affected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good move.

—A very good move. In order to assist families with special needs the Government has introduced a respite care pension. This means that special arrangements will be made to continue payments of the handicapped child's allowance for children who, for up to 28 days in any one year, are placed in an institution for respite care, thus enabling parents to have a holiday or a break. In addition, a new carer's pension will be introduced for people caring full time at home for a severely handicapped age or invalid pensioner spouse or near relative. This will replace the spouse carer's pension and extend pension entitlements for the first time to people caring at home for near relatives such as an ageing parent.

SPEECH.PARA: The Hawke Government, in its first two Budgets, provided some $1.2 billion in new and increased social security payments over and above the established indexation arrangements. This Budget now provides a further $110m in 1985-86 and $245m in a full year for increased benefits over and above indexation. In addition, the Government intends, subject to agreement with the States, to introduce legislation in this Budget session to establish a home and community care program to operate retrospectively from 1 July this year. The Budget provides for $117.5m to be spent on this program this financial year.

I wish to make a few short points in some other areas which, whilst they are not exclusive, I think are important points to be made. The Commonwealth Government will have direct spending on education this year totalling nearly $5 billion. This is an increase of 9.4 per cent and is a continuation of the strong growth in education funding that we have seen under this Government. The Government will also create an additional 5,500 places in higher education in 1986-87. Therefore, by 1987, 28,000 extra places will have been created in higher education since the election of the Hawke Government. Total housing outlays are expected to be nearly $1.4 billion. It is worth noting that this funding level means that total housing funds have increased by over 100 per cent since the final year of the Fraser Government. The Hawke Government's first home owners scheme has been extremely successful as every honourable member in this House would testify.

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly the honourable member for Kingston.

SPEECH.PARA: But before you cheer or even sigh with relief, remember that last night's statement was only the second instalment in a three-part drama.

Do not discard your flak jacket until you have heard the rest of the story. That will come in September's tax statement.

This Government likes to claim that it is a government of firsts. Opposition members who have been in this place for many years find that the Prime Minister has established yet another infamous first. Whoever heard of a Budget not including an administration's taxation proposals for the ensuing year? Fearful of adverse public reaction, the Government has watered down the Budget document to almost nothing, leaving significant economic statements to the May and September mini-Budgets. Even though Mr Keating has not told us what is in store for Australians, it is illuminating to consider briefly the record of this Government-this total economic disaster.

The Prime Minister has failed to destroy what he calls the myth surrounding the Australian Labor Party as a party of high taxation. The last 30 months have proved that Mr Hawke's myth is indeed reality. So much has been promised by Labor and so little has been delivered. People from all walks of life are now rightly suspicious that the much vaunted Hawke policy of taxation reform has been cremated, leaving the electorate to flounder in the ashes. Our marginal tax rates are biting in too early, they are disincentives and people rightly feel that they've got too high a rate of personal tax. So, for obvious reasons of personal hardship, incentives and economic efficiency we've got to bring those rates down and bring them down substantially.

Alas, Labor's Budget inactivity has shown the true extent of its failings. Labor gives worthless promises. It is now common knowledge that this Government simply cannot be trusted. The Treasurer asserted that there would be no tax increases, yet `pay as you earn' tax has been budgeted to increase by an enormous 13.3 per cent, with three-quarters of a million taxpayers moving into a higher tax bracket. To date, Labor's tax pledges have proved to be merely a fraudulent sham. The National Party has pointed out to the people of Australia the half truths, lies and distortions of this crumbling Government.

Let us consider a few relevant points. Under Labor Australians now will be paying higher taxes than ever before. With the latest PAYE increase our nation is facing a two-year tax grab which has been boosted by some 29 per cent. TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!

—It is wicked. Across the length and breadth of this country it is obvious that factions in the Australian Labor Party have not been able to agree on tax policy. The Treasurer and the New South Wales right wing faction move in one direction and the Centre Left in another, and the Socialist Left disagrees with everyone. Quite frankly, who knows where the Victorian independents stand? It is a classic case of the the right guard, the middle guard, the left guard and the mud guard. SPEECH.PARA: We in the National Party believe that Australian workers deserve a fair go; a fair day's pay for a fair day's work. This has long been held to be a fundamental principle but Labor positively discourages enterprise and people working longer hours to get ahead. The average person in our community wonders why the Government's taxation dam should be swelled to bursting point with heavily taxed overtime payments and work related benefits. As the editorial in the Sunday Sun of 25 August correctly stated:

Personal taxation is a fact of life, but it is not a licence for the Federal Government to print money. We in the National Party are implacably opposed to all such new Labor Party taxes. We opposed them during the last election campaign. We made our position clear during that election campaign. We advertised in the newspapers; and we emphasised our opposition over and over again. We stood up and we were counted. The National Party is the only party prepared to go to the barricades on this important issue. My colleague Senator Boswell stated our Party's position in no uncertain terms prior to the last election. I endorse Senator Boswell's words 100 per cent. What fools we would appear if we so stood up in the election campaign and opposed those taxes and, once we got to this place, we said: `The Labor Party has a mandate to introduce them and we will vote for them'.

As National Party members we were elected on the basis of opposition to capital gains taxes, wealth taxes, death taxes and gift taxes and we intend to pursue that opposition to the bitter end. We will vote against those taxes if introduced by Labor, both in this place and in the Senate. We do not apologise for this. We stand tonight and always before the people of Australia indicating our opposition to these taxes. Any conservative member in this place or the Senate who is prepared to vote for these taxes simply is not fit to sit as a member of the National-Liberal coalition. The National Party always stands up to be counted and I feel honoured to be a member of that Party in this place.

The Budget contains a number of problem areas for the Australian economy. Perhaps the most telling indication of this is the reaction of the Australian dollar and the trading on the stock market. The Australian dollar, after a small initial rise, fell below its pre-Budget level. In the week following the Budget the all ordinaries index fell 12 points from the pre-Budget level. The reason for this is quite simple: The business and financial markets are not fooled by the charade portrayed by the Treasurer. Like many of us, they have looked beneath the supposed sheen and polish of the apparently plausible surface assumptions and figures of the Budget Papers. The Hawke-Keating Budget contains some horrifying and very real outcomes that have the potential to impact substantially on the Australian economy, small business, employment and the rural sector. As the editor of a leading transport journal said of the Budget figures:

Contrary to Treasurer Paul Keating's predictions, the likely outcome of this Budget over the next 12 to 18 months is: higher inflation, higher interest rates, further falls in the dollar, unemployment remaining at about current levels, and growth in the economy at less than the Budget predictions.

Australia without doubt is becoming the Argentina of the Pacific. Indeed, the only supposed high point of the Labor Budget is the claimed reduction of the Budget deficit to $4.9 billion; that still means that $4,900m more than the Government earns is being dissipated by this profligate Government. While it is pleasing to see that the Government is endeavouring to trim back its deficit a little, the fact still remains that it is very much a record Budget deficit surpassed only by those of earlier Labor Budgets. Governments should run their affairs the same way as ordinary people have to.

Madam Deputy Speaker, imagine if your bank manager telephoned you and mentioned that your overdraft had blown out and that you were in the red, and you said: `I have gone into deficit budgeting. Don't worry, 30 June will come along and we will write off all that debt and start again'. I know what the bank manager would say. I very much doubt that he would continue the account. It is completely unacceptable for a government to spend more than it raises. The Queensland National Party Government has a balanced budget every year. It has been in government for many years and has a tremendous economic record; a record of which the whole of Australia and indeed the Western world can be proud.

Let us look at the efforts of the Labor Party Government compared with those of the coalition. In just three years the total Budget deficits of the overspending Hawke Government have totalled $19.5 billion-not million dollars, but billion dollars. By comparison in the 8 years or thereabouts of the Fraser-Anthony Government the coalition managed to keep the total accumulated deficit to some $20.9 billion. While no deficit is ideal, this means that this Government is overspending at the rate of almost three times that of its predecessor-and that is accepting the Treasurer's figures. I do not know whether we can accept his figures as they have so many rubbery aspects. Who knows what will happen in 12 months; who knows what Treasurer Keating will say to this House when he tries to present the Budget next year-that is, if he is still in that office. As Des Keegan, a very respected journalist, correctly stated in the Australian of 21 August:
If discounting for wage fixation after the sharp devaluation of the dollar is not realised the deficit will rise by several hundred million dollars.

Combine this with the probability that the forecast for growth is too high and the situation exists whereby revenue will be cut and expenditure boosted, thus forcing the Treasurer's magic deficit up further. Terry McCrann, Business Editor of the Melbourne Age, stated bluntly on 21 August:

If the Government fails to convince the ACTU to agree to deferral of part of the 3.8 per cent wage increase due under full wage indexation we can kiss goodbye to Mr Keating's Budget, his wider economic strategy, the economic recovery and indeed Mr Keating's and the Government's political future.

I am certain that honourable members on this side of the House would applaud the demise of this Government and there is no doubt that it simply does not have a future. The very fact that the success or otherwise of this Keating-Australian Council of Trade Unions Budget lies with the ACTU is frightening. The Treasurer has publicly argued that the Government will urge discounting. He will not grasp the nettle and say that there will be discounting; he says that it will merely urge discounting for the dollar effects of devaluation at the next two wage case hearings.

The Government is indeed taking a soft line with its economic master, the ACTU. The Government needs to state clearly, publicly and unequivocally that wage discounting must take place in the interests of the national economy. Not only does the union movement hold the pole position in this regard but also it holds the key as to whether the projected 1985-86 inflation rate of 8 per cent can be attained. At the whim of militant trade unions, Australia could well face an escalation of this figure and many respected commentators have indicated that the Treasurer would be exceptionally fortunate, or lucky, if he were able to contain the inflation rate to 8 per cent.

To achieve its forecast, the Government is relying heavily on a number of ifs and maybes. Central to these forecasts is a growth rate of 5 per cent, a situation that analysts are tipping to be highly improbable. To arrive at this growth, the Government is relying on a growth in business investment of 4 per cent or more and that in turn is heavily dependent on a relatively stable or improved value in the dollar, a reduction in interest rates, wage restraint and inflation being kept in check. Surely the Treasurer must be the ultimate optimist or is counting on a huge dose of economic good fortune.

Australia is facing a number of fundamental economic problems. It does not need the Hawke-Keating `ignore it and hopefully it will go away and solve itself' approach to the problem. Even the Treasurer's talk about the growth rate is clouded by a number of significant factors. In comparision with the situation in other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development economies, these problems appear quite obvious. A major stumbling block to recovery is the high level of interest rates which is cutting at the lifeblood of the productive business sector and is threatening business investment. Australia's current account deficit is now the second worst of all the major OECD countries. Australia has had the worst currency devaluation over the last 12 months and, taking into account discounting, it will have an inflation rate of nearly twice the forecast average of major OECD trading countries in 1986.

Even more alarming is the fact that there has been a large increase in our national and external debt. Under the Hawke Government, Australia has hit new levels of government spending. In turn, this spending is causing a high degree of borrowing with the resultant huge deficit previously mentioned and a spiralling international indebtedness. We need in this country a reduction in the size of the public sector. I mentioned privatisation earlier. We need privatisation or some return to the people of enterprises presently run by government. Privatisation has as its main effect a reduction in the size of the bureaucracy, a reduction in government spending and improved efficiency. In basic terms, this principle seeks to avoid a situation where the Government is the biggest consumer, the biggest employer and the biggest spender. In Australia today under this big spending, high taxing Hawke Labor Government, we are unfortunately approaching a terrible situation. Astute observers have carefully pointed out that the size of government and the public sector is on a continual increase. The Government has done little or nothing to alleviate this situation by getting rid of government enterprises and returning them to the people. By letting the people of Australia own these important enterprises, the Government would be taking a major and important step in the right direction.

Before I close, I congratulate our new Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong, and the new Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown). These two gentlemen will be superb performers; they will be superb leaders of our next Government, along with the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the Westminster system the moment when the Treasurer brings down the annual Budget is a moment of truth. I have in the past made this comment in a derogatory sense as I have watched the inescapable fiscal truths emanating from the 1981 Budget and particularly the 1982 Budget over which the then Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong and Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), presided. They gave the lie to his Leader's comments that the economy was improving and that unemployment was not an issue in Australia. In fact it was not until February 1983 that, given the impetus of an imminent Federal election, the Fraser-Howard duo went further than the infamously coined phrase `dole bludger', to consider belatedly the runaway results of their lack of manpower policies.

SPEECH.PARA: But the moment of truth which occurs when a democratic government must be accountable for its actions in straight tabulation of facts and figures can be enlightening in a number of ways. It can in fact be a credential for a government of credibility, underlining its direction and its policies. The 1985-86 Budget is such a document. It is a Budget which is aimed not only at continuing the mammoth task of pulling Australia out of the economic trough into which it had fallen prior to March 1983; it is a Budget which aims also at realising the full potential of the Australian society as a caring society.

Concern at the large number of young people who leave school only to join the ranks of the unemployed has moved the Federal Government to introduce several new projects to help young Australians. These projects, under the heading `Priority One: Young Australia', were funded under the recent Federal Budget and will commence in 1986. They cover the area of job traineeships, actual jobs, education, income support and other support for young people wanting employment. Priority One offers entirely new job training opportunities which have not existed before. It is not just a rehash of old schemes. I mention this because it is important that if the project is to be successful, all sectors of the community must be informed of the new opportunities before them.

For young people Priority One offers the chance to gain further education and training after leaving school to compete more effectively in the labour market. This will be provided through a large scale vocational employment traineeship program that combines on the job training with formal off the job training for a minimum 12-month period in a recognised training institution. This is not an apprenticeship but a new traineeship giving formal work qualifications. There will also be a financial incentive to pursue further education through the provision of simplified, rational and generous income support for young people.

The Government has allocated $15.7m for the program in 1985-86 to create 10,000 traineeships for 16-17-year olds. In 1988 the number of trainees will increase to 75,000. For parents, Priority One offers the promise of greater employment security for children, as well as relief of the financial burden of higher education. In the past larger benefits have been paid to young adults looking for work-unemployment benefits-than to people who wish to gain educational qualifications; that is the tertiary education assistance scheme. This has denied many youngsters the educational opportunities which they deserve. By 1989 the rates of income support will be equalised to help young unemployed people return to education or training without fear of a reduction in government financial support. There will also be an additional 20,000 places in higher education created by 1988.

For business people, Priority One offers an incentive to help young people gain employment experience through vocational traineeships. This will have significant long term benefits for the private sector as a pool of well-trained, adaptable and experienced young people will soon enter the work force. The Government will provide an on-the-job training fee of $1,000 per trainee for employers for the 12-month period and an off-the-job training fee of $1,700 per trainee paid to technical and further education colleges and $2,000 for other training institutions for the 12-month period. In addition, there will be a number of youth support initiatives at community level to meet the special needs of young people. Employment must be adequate at every level. The Federal Government does not forget the older person who is out of a job. But this program is being sponsored by the Federal Government in the belief that the onus falls on governments, as on all Australians, to ensure that the years ahead will be secure and prosperous for today's young people. We believe in young Australia and we believe in putting our money where our mouth is.

It should be noted that $2.9m has been allocated to the Commonwealth Employment Service to upgrade and rationalise CES and to provide for the creation of special youth centres within CES offices. There has been a 23 per cent increase in funding for the community youth support scheme and $1.5m will be spent on the youth services development program. The group volunteer community services scheme has had an allocation of $1m. There has also been housing assistance. Under the supported accommodation assistance program the Government will provide low cost and crisis accommodation for young people-$4.4m in 1985-86. The community employment program will receive $290m for 30,000 more jobs in 1985-86 and 105,000 people will have received job training by 1986.

If one compares the record of this Government with that of our predecessors on the question of employment, one finds that an enormous gulf exists in the serious formulation of effective employment policies, particularly for young people. This Government has sought tangible solutions to the problem of unemployment through stimulation of the economy and direct government employment creation as is evidenced by the highly successful community employment program. In contrast, under the leadership of Malcolm Fraser and John Howard, our opponents adopted a regressive and ineffective monetarist approach which sought to bring down inflation, but at the cost of jobs. The irony was that the outcome of this policy neither reduced unemployment nor reduced inflation. In fact, the opposite occurred, as the economy lurched into unnecessary recession and the social and economic problems of unemployment seriously affected our society. Now again the Opposition advocates a more stringent needs based approach to welfare. The Labor Government agrees that welfare payments are meant to cover those in need, not the affluent or the comfortably situated, but it is most important that we do not make scapegoats of one parent families. The Opposition Leader in the Senate, Senator Chaney, is quoted in today's Australian as saying:
there had been no person in the Fraser cabinet more concerned at relieving genuine hardship than Mr Howard . . .
To continue the quote:
but the nation had to come to grips with the `reality' of the problems for supporting parents.

If Senator Chaney thinks that Mr Howard, with his record of turning his back on the huge unemployment problems when he was in office, is the epitome of Opposition concern, I await with dread what he sees as the reality, the final solution for lone parents striving to rear their children in Australia.

I wish to outline some of the ways in which this Government will help low income families. This year the Government has again increased payments for low income families. For people on pensions or benefits, the additional tax free payment for children will increase from $14 a week for each child to $16 a week from November 1985. This increase means that since the Government won office it has lifted the additional pension benefit for children by 60 per cent. For low income families not receiving a pension or benefit, the maximum rate of family income supplement will increase from $14 to $16 a week per child, also from November 1985. Families earning less than $229 a week may qualify for this maximum payment, with some payments continuing to be available to families whose incomes exceed this limit by up to $32 a week per child. This new level of payment represents a 60 per cent increase since the benefit was introduced in May 1983. From May 1986 the tax-free mothers-guardian allowance, which is paid to sole parent pensioners or beneficiaries, will increase by $2 a week to $12 per family. This payment will then be up to 100 per cent higher than it was at the time Labor won office.

In acting to redistribute resources to those most in need, the Government has increased and expanded benefits for the unemployed. When the Hawke Government came to office single unemployed people had slipped far behind all other welfare recipients because of the discriminatory actions of the previous Government in denying them the indexation increases available to pensioners and other beneficiaries. This year's Budget again acts to close the gap between pensions and unemployment benefits for those aged 21 and over, by providing a special $3 increase over and above normal indexation. As a result, the gap between the standard pension rate and the unemployment benefit for people over 21 will, from November 1985, be only $6.45-half of what it was in 1983. The new rate of this benefit from November-$91.45 a week-will be $27 higher than it was when Labor won office less than three years ago.

For the first time, rent assistance will be available from May 1986 to people aged 18 and over who have been on benefits for six months or more and are renting privately; to people who are over the age of 24, married or have dependent children; or to people aged 18 to 24 who are not living with parents or guardians. From May 1986 unemployed people will also be able to earn up to $30 a week in allowable income and still qualify for full payments. This represents a practical step taken by the Government towards alleviating the problem of poverty traps and it means that beneficiaries will be on a more equal footing with single pensioners.

Other provisions include respite care. Special arrangements will be made to continue payments of the handicapped child's allowance for children who, for up to 28 days in any one year, are placed in an institution for respite care, thus enabling parents to have a holiday or break. A new carer's pension will be introduced for people caring full time at home for a severely handicapped age or invalid pensioner spouse or near relative. This will replace the spouse carer's pension and extend pension entitlement for the first time to people who are caring at home for near relatives, such as an aging parent.

No government with any claim to meeting the needs of the nation can turn its back on the poor. A nation is only as healthy as its most disadvantaged citizen. The Opposition consistently makes a basic mistake when it harasses those who are on welfare. Opposition members mistakenly believe that if what is virtually a Red Cross operation is performed on behalf of children who are victims of broken marriages, that operation of mercy causes broken marriages. That is not so. The Hawke Government shares the concern at the number of marriages that are breaking up, but we believe that the children of those marriages should not be made doubly the victims by government penalising in the guise of thrift, as has been suggested by Opposition spokespeople. While the Government is striving to assist couples with large families and the unemployed, available statistics show that Australian children in one parent families are victims. In 1981-82 of the 1.9 million Australians in poverty, 841,000 were dependent children. Further, in all States, Territories and regions, the percentage in poverty is highest for children in one-parent families. We as a nation cannot moralise on the source of their distress, both children and parents, and turn our backs on them. We as a government do not intend to do so. There is an obvious need for policies which support rather than scapegoat people such as the victims of marriage breakup and of scarce jobs, people who are down on their luck. The 1985-86 Budget seeks to fill that need.

But the truth regarding the Federal Budget is that for this to be comprehensive it must be viewed in context with preceding and immediately following Budgets. This Budget is part of a plan over a number of years for a caring society, a plan incorporating the accord, the Priority One youth strategy, the home and community care program, and various other programs assisting those in need. Who pays for this caring society? In any democracy, it is the taxpayer who pays for all programs emanating from a government. No government has additional funds coming from any source. But the burden must be shared; the tax must be equitable. There is, therefore, a need for tax reform. There has been such a need for years, but no previous government has had the guts to risk the political flak which would result from tax reform. The Hawke Government has that determination and is willing to accept short term criticism from those to whom tax reform means only tax cuts and tax cuts for all, in order to benefit all Australians in the long term. John Valder, National President of the Liberal Party, has said:
Let the Labor Party get on with implementing the more necessary but perhaps less popular parts of our policy. And let's hope they get them into place and promptly lose office.

High sounding ideals! But a caring society need not result only from the annihilation of the reform government which achieves it. I believe that in conjunction with policies spanning the next two years, this Budget and this Government will achieve a caring society and will survive.
