SPEECH.PARA: The third Budget will be brought down in September. I am told that it will contain the dreaded capital gains taxes. However, most of my comments tonight are concerned with the second Budget, brought down in August, which can best be described as a Clayton's Budget-a Budget that you have when you are not having a Budget. Nevertheless, I remember it for four things. The first, is the removal of the 15 per cent tariff on header harvesters, to be replaced by a bounty. I compliment the Government on doing that. The National Party has been asking for that since the tariff was implemented in 1983, and now it has been removed. The only difficulty is that in the two years in which it applied, it cost the grain growers of this country $30m. I am told that it will apply only to headers imported after 21 August this year. What about the headers that are already on machinery dealers' lots having been brought into this country? When a farmer fronts up to buy headers, he will not buy particularly those that were imported before then. This will create quite a difficulty. I hope that the Government will rectify that anomaly.

The second thing for which I remember the Budget is the 2.4c per litre diesel rebate, which was restored. It should never have been removed. Its removal cost the farmers of Australia $55m. The National Party and the Liberal Party have been pressing the Government to restore that, and this has finally been granted. I compliment the Government on doing that.

The third thing is the $5 billion deficit, which has been much trumpeted. Nevertheless, it is worth remembering that that is the third highest deficit in our history, after the deficit of 1983-84 and the deficit of 1984-85. It is a sorry day for Australia when a $5 billion deficit is heralded as a great achievement.

The fourth thing for which I remember the Budget is the large increase in taxes for the average worker. This comes after the much vaunted tax summit in July. We had 500,000 taxpayers sucked into the 46c bracket last year. Now, on top of that, we are to have another 500,000 taxpayers sucked into that same 46c bracket for this year. In addition, another 250,000 taxpayers will move up into the 60c bracket. Most of these are just average wage earners. Pay as you earn taxpayers will pay 13.3 per cent more tax this year. With inflation estimated at 8 per cent, that is bad news indeed. The PAYE taxpayers will be paying an extra 29 per cent over the last two years.

Despite all the rhetoric about being grand economic managers, this Government, nevertheless, is the highest taxing and highest spending government in Australia's history. The story of economic improvement about which the Government keeps telling us is at best a half truth. Sure, there was some economic improvement, but it was not due to government policy. Three things fell into the Government's lap. The American economy, under Ronald Reagan, came good. That virtually halved inflation right around the world, Australia included. Secondly, the drought broke and that gave a great impetus to the economy of this country. Thirdly, the benefits of the Fraser-Anthony Government wages pause flowed through the Australian economy, but took 18 months to two years to do so.

But all that is now over, and the jobs and growth about which we keep hearing and which the Government keeps claiming it has produced are mainly created now by deficit spending and Public Service expansion. Very few jobs have been created in the private sector. Most have been created in the public sector. Over one in four jobs are now in the public sector, and that ratio is increasing rapidly.

The deficit is a very misunderstood term. We tend to talk only about the $5 billion deficit for this year; but that is only this year's deficit. It is really the cumulative deficit that should worry us. Not only do we have this year's deficit but we have last year's deficit to pay off, and the deficit of the year before that, and the deficit of the year before that. If a small businessman borrows, say, $50,000 this year, he not only has to pay that back but also has to repay the $100,000 that he borrowed the year before, and the $50,000 that he borrowed the year before that. It all adds up. All of it must be repaid.

TALK.START.PARA: —Interest has to be paid on it, too.

—That is right. In 1970-71 the total public debt of this country was $15.1 billion. In 1983-84 it had risen to $75.3 billion. The figure has risen since then, and next year it is estimated that it will top $100 billion.

SPEECH.PARA: The story with interest payments is no different. In 1970-71 interest payments to service the debt were $0.98 billion, but in 1983-84 the figure had risen to $8.5 billion. The figure is expected soon to top $10 billion. The average rate of interest paid in 1970-71 was 6.5 per cent. In 1983-84 that had risen to 11.3 per cent, and it is higher than that now. But what is particularly alarming is the average length of each debt or loan that is written. The average maturity period nearly halved from almost 8 1/2 years in 1978 to 4 1/2 years in 1983 and it is shorter now. This means in simple language that as the old loans are rolled over new ones are negotiated at higher and higher interest rates for shorter and shorter periods. The pattern has now been clearly established for a major financial crisis some few years down the track. Already it seems we inhabit a fool's paradise.

Our total national debt in June 1985 figures was estimated to be $6,000 per person or $14,000 per employee or, looking at it another way, $19,000 per family. It is our children and grandchildren who will have to bail us out. Both political sides are at fault. Public sector spending-government spending-in Australia has exceeded government income in almost every year this century. It presently exceeds income by 15 per cent. Under the Whitlam regime spending in real terms increased by 10 per cent each year. Under the Fraser-Anthony Government that increase in real terms fell to 2 per cent a year, and under the Hawke-Crean regime it has been close to 7 per cent in the two-plus years Labor has been in government. The deficit is increasing and when plotted on a graph shows a steeply rising curve. It has to be serviced and that is what interest payments are, and they too are taking a steeply rising curve.

As I said, in the early 1970s the interest payment was less than $1 billion and it is just under $10 billion today and increasing at the rate of 30 per cent a year. It is money down the drain, down the gurgle hole. We are spending more on interest-I am not talking about the repayment of the debt-than we do on defence, education and health together. The debt per person is higher in this country than in Third World countries such as Brazil, Mexico and Argentina. It is only our ability to service that debt that still gives us our triple A credit rating, which surely must soon come down. We have the highest real interest rates since the Depression. What is the cure for this? It is to spend no more than what we earn. In fact we should spend less at first. We should not increase taxes and pass the debt on to our children and cripple them with the repayments. We must restore the incentive to do productive work in this country. We must restore the incentive to take a risk, to invest, to earn a decent living for productive work. There is no incentive to do any of these things any more. On official government figures the average farmer earns little more than $150 a week. The small businessman earns about $150 a week also. There is incentive to be only a wage earner and to work from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. and to have no capital outlay. The wage earner is better off than those who invest capital, create the jobs, take the risks, meet the interest bills and the on-costs, do the paper work, put in the long hours and take the responsibility. The only thing left for the small businessman is the capital gain at the end of his working career. That is his superannuation, and if the Government takes that away from him in September when it brings down its third Budget small business and the rural community will collapse. To reverse this the Government should not have held a tax summit in July but an expenditure summit. If it spends less it will not have to collect as much tax.

The area in which cuts can be made is enormous. Two broad areas are Medicare and social security. We have already heard in this debate about the single parent supporting benefit. To correct the economic mess that we are in we would have to deal with many areas. We have heard of privatisation. The Australian National Line will be one of the first to go. We need the deregulation of government protected monopolies in this country. If we are going to change the tax system we should be moving towards a flat tax. We need every able bodied person in this country working for the dole. We need the deregulation of our wage fixing system, including the abolition of compulsory unionism, and we need very much lower tariff protection.

Before finishing I would like to mention one item that came up in Supply Bill (No. 1) earlier this year because it epitomises what is wrong with what this Government is doing and what is wrong with this country today. There was an item in that Bill to collect $32m from the taxpayers of Australia to give to a mining company here. Honourable members might ask why this Hawke-Crean Government is taking taxpayers' money to give to a mining company in Australia. It is because the Government was buying uranium from Queensland Mines Ltd which was destined for the French electricity authority. As honourable members know, France generates about 65 per cent of its electricity from uranium because it is cheap, clean, safe and its consumers demand it. Many countries in Europe use uranium to generate electricity and the number is increasing. France buys its uranium from many sources as it is a very common element in the earth's crust. It wanted to buy some from us. In August 1981 the electricity authority contracted Queensland Mines to deliver 2,600 tonnes of uranium from Australia to France between 1982 and 1988. Queensland Mines had already shipped 900 tonnes and it had 1,700 tonnes to go before the Labor Government moved in. The uranium was due to be sent in 100-tonne lots, with each shipment worth about $7m in export income earnings for this country.

This money should have been paid to Queensland Mines last year when the Government stopped the shipment but the appropriation was deferred. Honourable members might ask why and I will tell them. There was an election in December and the Government would have looked particularly silly if it had not deferred the payment and it would have been a very costly thing to do. It stopped sending uranium because of an Australian Labor Party Conference decision, which was decided by left wingers and union delegates. Even worse, the ALP has been a slave to the Left on this. It has already smashed the ANZUS alliance with the MX missile fiasco. That is where this $32m went; it was merely a sop to the Left. Of course the amount will be more than $32m later on; the total amount will be in excess of $119m.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would help the sugar industry.

—That is right. The honourable member may ask what the Government is going to do with this uranium it is buying from Queensland Mines. It will be stockpiled with the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, which is a sheer and utter waste. It may as well go out and dig holes and fill them in again. The jobs of the miners of this country will be put in jeopardy. The consumers of France will be inconvenienced. However, they will still get their uranium elsewhere. It would take just a phone call to Canada or South Africa-the country that honourable members opposite love-and the contracts could be filled. This merely adds up to a loss of export income to Australia of $119m.

SPEECH.PARA: Even worse, there is the danger of France retaliating against Australia. Last year France dumped beef on the Canadian market, and there is the threat it may dump more. It has high stockpiles of sugar and dairy products. If it has to dump them who would blame it? Many of my constituents in the Parkes electorate are very worried about this retaliatory action. The Government's action damages our reputation for reliability and it shows that we are reneging on yet another contract. We have become the laughing stock of the world and Canada, South Africa and other countries which are replacing us in uranium contracts are laughing all the way to the bank. Europe is using thousands and thousands of tonnes of uranium each year. None of Australia's uranium is used in making weaponry, but members of the Left cannot see that. It is beyond their comprehension, and I suppose I cannot blame them for that. However, I expected the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to know better; he should not tolerate this poppycock and sheer waste of taxpayers' money. It amounts to a criminal action, and the Australian people should be told about it.

The Government should at least tell us how the $32m is made up. No doubt there is a large component of interest charges and I would like to hear about the devaluation effect from the collapsing value of the Australian dollar brought about by similar policies. I have never heard of a more unnecessary, a more blatant or a more stupid waste of taxpayers' money than this. The Government should stand condemned for its imbecility. The total amount of $119m plus interest and other charges that must ultimately be paid is more than the cost of the petroleum freight subsidy scheme which was abolished in May and is more than the money which will be saved as a result of the assets test on pensioners. It is hard to believe that the Government could have such a blatant and total disregard for taxpayers' money by supporting this futile and wasteful action simply to keep the rabid left wing back bench silent. The Australian people must be told about this and similar actions so that they can ultimately condemn the Government at the ballot boxes at the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure to support the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) because the Budget which it deals with builds upon the Labor Government's first two Budgets and it pursues our great goals of economic growth and a fairer society. This Budget has a clear and positive direction. It distributes many of the benefits of Australia's renewed economic growth. In short and simple terms, it means more jobs, a lower deficit, a new start for youth, assistance for our primary producers and help for the many families who are in need throughout Australia. The 1985-86 Budget is a program for growth and reform. In summary terms, it is a Budget for jobs and for a fairer Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Hawke Government came to office in March 1983 we promised to seek renewed economic growth and, above all, to get Australians working again. We brought to government an economic policy based on the prices and incomes accord, with progressively less stimulatory fiscal policy and responsible monetary policy, and we set ourselves a number of inter-related goals. The first of those goals was to create half a million new jobs in our first three years in office. Our second goal was to reduce unemployment and inflation simultaneously. Our third goal was to improve permanently our long term growth performance by correcting structural weaknesses in the economy and, over time, to acheive a more just and equitable society.

The approach of the Government, and in particular the emphasis which we placed on the prices and incomes accord, was framed in recognition of the environment within which any Australian government would naturally have to work. In my view, all Australians can now be proud of the fact that as a nation we have made an enormous amount of progress towards achieving those goals. Australia has experienced one of the strongest recoveries among all of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. We have already had 10 per cent real growth over the last two years. In Australia we are looking forward to a further 5 per cent of real non-farm growth during the period of the 1985-86 Budget, while the OECD expects only 3 per cent for the world's major industrial countries.

The strong growth evident under this Government has been the key to the 410,000 new jobs that have been created in Australia since the National Economic Summit Conference in April 1983. I shall correct a misunderstanding in the speech some moments ago of the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) when he suggested that most of those jobs were in the public sector. I refer the honourable member to the latest Australian Bureau of Statistics figures which show very clearly that of the 130,000 new jobs created in the last 12 months, more than 90 per cent of the growth has come from the private sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —He wasn't far out, was he?

—He was not far out. He said they were all from the public sector, but more than 90 per cent of the increase has occurred in the private sector. So it is a myth that this Government is a big pump-priming government, pushing out bigger and bigger deficits to create public funded jobs. Some 90 per cent of the 130,000 new jobs in the last 12 months have been created in the private sector. To put the performance of this Government in context, I point out that we have created 70,000 more jobs in just over two years than the Fraser Government managed in its whole seven years. Our three-year target of 500,000 new jobs is now very comfortably within reach. The unemployment rate has already fallen by two percentage points and on the basis of this Budget's estimates we expect it to fall to 7 1/2 per cent next year or, at the very worst, to 8 per cent. At the same time, even though recently there has been some pick up in prices in response to depreciation, the annual increase in prices in this past year has been the lowest since 1970-71. Industrial disputation is at the lowest level for one and a half years.
—What about profits?

—My colleague mentioned profits. Business profitability has now been restored to historically high levels. Real unit labour costs have been reduced to levels which were last seen in the early 1970s. These are all achievements which our opponents who are so vocal now could never match. In this environment of very strong private sector growth and renewed economic confidence, the Government has been able substantially to reduce its outlays in the 1985-86 Budget. In this Budget, we have reduced the growth of real outlays to 1.3 per cent. That is the lowest rate of real increase in six years. Perhaps, even more impressively, this Budget has the lowest nominal growth of outlays since 1968-69-almost 18 years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: In this Budget there has been no increase in tax revenue as a proportion of gross domestic product, and the Government has reduced the deficit by $1.8 billion to $4.9 billion. That is a major reduction. In that respect, this year's Budget represents a mere 2.1 per cent of gross domestic product. For the information of honourable members in cockies' corner, which is to my right, that is well under half of the prospective ratio that we inherited in 1983 from the discredited Fraser and Howard Government.

Before proceeding to specific aspects of the Appropriation Bill as they affect my electorate of Bendigo, it is necessary to put this Budget and the Government's economic achievements in the proper context. When we think back to 1983 we well recall that Australia had endured seven very long and arduous years of Liberal rule. They were years which were based on confrontation and division and which reaped a debilitating wage price spiral and economic stagnation. It was a period of rule which earned for the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), now Opposition Leader and the then Treasurer, the dubious distinction of being the only Treasurer in Australia's history to preside over both double digit inflation and double digit unemployment. In that period under the now Opposition Leader unemployment figures jumped to double digits. Profits dived to their lowest levels ever. The number of industrial disputes and real labour unit costs hit historically high figures and we saw the destruction of Australia's once excellent international competitiveness.

In contrast with those dark days of the Howard-Fraser years which, I am reminded, saw the attempted sale of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory-a period in which the now Opposition Leader was Treasurer-the Hawke Government's third Budget is a very good Budget for the Bendigo electorate. When as a result of the Liberal Party leadership challenge last week the honourable member for Bennelong was elected as the new Opposition Leader, many people in Bendigo were appalled because the present Opposition Leader was Treasurer when the Fraser Government attempted to sell the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. The previous Opposition Leader, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), was a regular visitor to the Bendigo electorate. I can only extend a very warm welcome to the current Opposition Leader, the honourable member for Bennelong, to Bendigo. I am sure that many groups and organisations would like to discuss some of his economic policies with him. To begin with, I imagine that about 600 employees of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory would be very keen to see him. He has never had the courage to come to Bendigo and speak to them directly. I am sure that they would like the opportunity now to speak to him.

There are approximately 1,000 Australia Post and Telecom Australia employees throughout north central Victoria. Their jobs would be seriously under threat were a Liberal government with its privatisation proposals ever returned in this country. I am sure that those people would also like to talk to the honourable member for Bennelong. So I am very pleased to extend to him the invitation to visit my electorate on whatever occasion he might like.

I have mentioned that, in contrast to the policies which might be introduced and which historically have been introduced by the present Opposition Leader, the current Budget, the Hawke Government's third Budget, is a very good Budget for the Bendigo electorate. There are many initiatives in this Budget which will consolidate and stimulate the strengthening signs of economic and job growth in country Victoria. Perhaps the most important of those initiatives as they affect my area, which is an electorate of approximately 15,000 square kilometres, are the initiatives we took in regard to the rural sector. I refer in particular to the full rebate of diesel fuel excise for fuel which is used in primary production, at a cost this year to the Government of approximately $35m. That initiative has been welcomed by grain producers, in particular, throughout my electorate. Another rural initiative that has been welcomed is the decision in relation to grain harvester bounties. Those bounties will be introduced to replace the existing tariffs on imported harvesters. That is being done at a cost to the Government of $14m in a full year. I was very encouraged to read after the Budget the statements in the local Bendigo news- paper, the Bendigo Advertiser, by various farming groups applauding the Government's initiatives in these two areas.

Another rural initiative of particular benefit to my electorate is the funding for the national soil conservation program which has been increased by 16 per cent or $600,000. We have an excellent program in the Bendigo electorate located at Bourkes Flat which is between Wedderburn and St Arnaud in a very badly eroded and dry land salting area of my electorate. To date the Federal Government has put more than $50,000 into that program. It is a program which operates with enormous support from the farmers and the Victorian Soil Conservation Authority and with Federal Government funding. I am pleased that we have introduced increased funding nationally for that program because I know that it and many other programs will benefit. Another rural initiative of benefit to my electorate is the money provided under the national water resources program. I am very pleased to see that the Commonwealth has offered the State Government $86,000 for flood mitigation works to be undertaken on Bendigo Creek.

Another area of particular importance to my electorate is housing assistance. I am very pleased to see in this Budget that continued funding is being made available under the Government's highly successful first home owners scheme. The scheme has made an enormous contribution to renewed growth in the building industry throughout Australia. Perhaps nowhere has this contributioin been more apparent than in the Federal electorate of Bendigo. To date more than 1,500 families and individuals have been approved and have received grants of up to $6,000 under the first home owners scheme. To put that in its proper perspective, the June quarter housing statistics which have just come through for the greater Bendigo area show that for the first time new housing approvals for the June quarter have topped the $10m mark. That compares with the $3.3m of new housing approvals under the last full quarter of the Fraser Government. The figure has tripled-an increase of 200 per cent. I am pleased to see that the first home owners scheme is being continued and supported so strongly by the Government.

The other area under the category of housing which is of importance to my electorate is the local government and community housing program. From my point of view it is very pleasing to see that there has been a substantial increase in funds of 40 per cent for this housing program which assists local government and community groups to provide low cost rental accommodation for families in need. In the Bendigo electorate, the burrough of Eaglehawk and the Bendigo arm of the Salvation Army have shown enthusiastic support for the program. They were recently amongst what was only a very small number-14 in total, I think-of Victorian projects which received the first allocation of funding under this housing program. It is a good program, and it can now be expanded with the additional funding we have made available in this Budget.

Honourable members would be well aware that this Budget contains a number of very positive measures in the Government's continued attack on poverty in Australia. I particularly welcome this continuing attack on poverty. If one looks at the make-up, the constituency of the Federal electorate of Bendigo, one sees that on an income per head basis, according to Census statistics, it is the second poorest electorate of the more than 30 Federal electorates in Victoria and the tenth poorest of the 148 Federal electorates around Australia. So I certainly welcome any initiatives that the Government takes to address poverty.

In this Budget we have increased family allowances, mothers and guardians allowances and the family income supplement. The increase in the family income supplement means that 120 families throughout my electorate will now get an increase in income support. I am equally pleased that in this Budget we have been able to increase the level of income support for single unemployed individuals. It is a very timely boost to the living standards of this group. In the area of education and youth honourable members will be aware that a major area of reform in this Budget is the spearhead of the Government's Priority One strategy for Australian youth. I am particularly pleased to see the introduction of youth traineeships. However, that is just one aspect of a four-part plan we have introduced to provide a totally new start for young Australians.

In the area of youth allowances new incentives will be given to young people and their families for young people to remain at secondary school longer and to be able to participate in tertiary education with more support from the Government. There will be a substantial increase in secondary allowances next year and progressive increases in the secondary allowance scheme and the tertiary education assistance scheme to 1988. The new income support system for youth will greatly assist young people and their families in the electorate of Bendigo. The 700 TEAS recipients who are currently at the Bendigo College of Advanced Education will also benefit from the increases we have provided in this area.

The last thing I say in regard to specific aspects of the Budget relates to the extra places the Government is providing in tertiary education. The Bendigo College of Advanced Education was notified under last year's program that it will be getting increases in new student places to 1988. I am sure that the Budget decision to provide another 5,000 places, building on the previous 15,000 places, and giving a total of 20,000 new higher education and tertiary education places by 1988, will also benefit the Bendigo College of Advanced Education which plays such an important role educationally in the region.

As a provincial and rural member representing a seat of about 15,000 square kilometres I would be remiss in my duty in debate on these Appropriation Bills if I did not conclude my remarks with some comments about privatisation, as it has become known, and its possible effects on country people. We have heard a number of speakers opposite tonight mention this topic. While this Budget is a very good one for country people, there is in my mind no greater threat to rural people than the mindless calls-that is what they are-by the Leader of the Opposition and the shadow Treasurer for the sale of Telecom Australia and Australia Post. This Budget retains Telecom and Australia Post. Were our opponents ever to regain government-that is at best many years away-they have made it fairly clear that Telecom and Australia Post are on the list of organisations to be sold or, at the very least, that parts of them would be sold and parts of them taxed.

It has been suggested that Telecom profits could be taxed. In response to a question asked during Question Time today, the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) indicated that if Telecom were taxed it would add approximately 5c or 6c to the cost of a local call in Australia, An increase in tariff of 40 per cent would result simply from the taxing of Telecom. The impact on country subscriber trunk dialling charges would be severe, probably the same in percentage terms as the impact of taxing Telecom, but enormous in money terms. If Telecom was not taxed under the Opposition's plans it would be sold. Let us look at what the sale of Telecom means. Telecom currently cross-subsidises rural consumers to the tune of $500m a year. We have had mindless calls from members of the Opposition who perhaps do not appreciate that 20 per cent of Telecom's profits are generated from one square kilometre in the Sydney business district. They do not appreciate that $500m of cross-subsidy is going towards keeping the cost of country calls down. All the research that is being done shows that if we sold off the profitable sections of Telecom, the golden boomerang going round the coast, we would double STD charges. Rentals would be on a charging scale directly related to distance. Some people 10 kilometres from Bendigo would be paying $1,000 a year in rent.

I raised this matter because I believe there is no greater threat to country people and their welfare than the mindless calls of the spineless morons opposite who continue to promote the privatisation of Telecom. That is the simple fact of the matter. It is about time that the members of cockies' corner had a bit of backbone and stood up for country people. They have been silent to date. Some of their own members are calling for privatisation. Be that on their heads. But how they can ever justify the sale of Telecom and Australia Post as members of the National Party of Australia, allegedly concerned about rural interests, totally defies my imagination and the imagination of the people of my electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Federal Budget brought down by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 20 August was my first Budget as a new member of parliament. I looked forward to it, as all new members of parliament do, with a great deal of anticipation. Unfortunately, as the night progressed I found that my anticipation was unfounded. Quite frankly, the Budget that was brought down by this Hawke socialist Government was a singular disappointment to me and, I know, to the large majority of Australians. It was a singular disappointment because at the very best it could be said that this Budget brought down by the Hawke socialist Government is half a Budget. The other half of the Budget will be announced in this chamber on 19 September. That other half of the Budget will contain all the nasty aspects of what the Hawke socialist Government is all about. It will contain aspects that people in Australia do not want. Who in Australia wants a capital gains tax? The left wing rabble of the Australian Labor Party might want a capital gains tax but, Mr Deputy Speaker, I can assure you that the average Australian man or woman does not want a capital gains tax. Farmers do not want a capital gains tax. Small businessmen do not want capital gains taxes. People who rent accommodation do not want capital gains taxes.

SPEECH.PARA: People who rent accommodation know that the New South Wales State Minister, Frank Walker said-the only sensible words that he has ever said-that if a capital gains tax is introduced we can expect to see the cost of rental accommodation increase substantially. People who rent accommodation do not want capital gains taxes because they know, as any sensible Australian knows, that a person who owns rented accommodation wants to make a fair return. Under the present system they are making a fair return by getting a capital gain. If we tax that capital gain those property owners will still want to get a fair return. They will get it by putting up the cash rental of that accommodation. That cash will come out of the back pockets of the ordinary working men and women of this country. They will be the people who will be disadvantaged by a capital gains tax. They are the people this socialist Labor Government claims to be representing.

There are other nasty aspects that we can look forward to on 19 September. The capital gains tax is just part of it. Attached to that capital gains tax will be death and gift duties. Anyone with a memory and anyone with a degree of common sense will know that any form of death or gift duties will seriously disadvantage Australians and seriously discriminate against the major proportion of Australia's popluation.

In 1983 the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promised the people of Australia that under his Government taxes would be cut. We can now look back on the track record of this Hawke socialist Government and see that this year the taxpaying community will be paying 13.4 per cent more to the Government's coffers than it did the year before. The year before that it contributed an extra 14.2 per cent to the Government's coffers. The taxpaying community had to do that because this Government is the highest taxing, highest spending government in Australia's history. We find that income tax revenue now forms 50 per cent of the Government's total revenue. Some 20 years ago income tax revenue formed 36 per cent of the Federal Government's total revenue. The pay as you earn taxpayer is bearing more and more of the burden of government expenditure.

The Prime Minister promised the people of Australia at the last election that we would have a tax summit. He said that, at that tax summit, we would see tax reform that he claimed would take away the burden of this expensive government from the PAYE taxpayer and spread it more evenly around the community. But what did we get out of the tax summit? We got nothing. It was a failure. It was a flop. It was a sham. It was a disgrace. All we got was the Prime Minister making a trip to a motel in Canberra to do a deal with the Australian Council of Trade Unions. In essence that is what this Government is all about. This Government is under the guidance of the ACTU and the unions. Without their approval this Government cannot govern. The trip that the Prime Minister made was symbolic. Wise and wonderful people from all over Australia gathered at the tax summit to offer this Government their advice. We saw how those people's advice was ignored by the Prime Minister. I guess the tax summit can be summed up in the words of the Queensland Premier, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, when he was talking about attending it. He said: `I attended the tax summit. When I got there we talked about option C, option B and Option A and we ended up adopting option ACTU'. As I said earlier, the ACTU is what this Government is all about.

There is an urgent need for tax reform in Australia. There is no doubt that the present tax system creates disincentive for people to strive, to work hard and to create income. This matter was brought up at the tax summit and it received no hearing from the Government. As the debate about a flat rate of tax takes place in the community there is no question that this form of taxation can be seen as real tax reform. It creates real incentive for people to work hard and to achieve. It does away with the disincentive for those working that little bit harder and finding, as they work harder, that they end up losing more and more to the Government's coffers. I will use the classic example of the shearers of this nation to illustrate the disincentive that the present tax system creates. Shearers will often not work until finishing time at 5.30. They will often knock off at 4.30. They do so because they say: `If we shear any more sheep and earn any more money we will end up moving into the next tax bracket and we will lose 60c of every dollar that we earn as we shear those extra sheep. If we have a flat rate of tax we will find that a person earning $1 or $1m will still pay the same proportion of income to the Government. That will create incentive for people such as shearers to work on from 4.30 to 5.30. It will create incentive for those people who work in mines that operate 24 hours a day to do a Sunday shift or an additional shift once a week to earn that extra bit of money because they know that they will not be disadvantaged as a result of working another hour or two. As has so often been pointed out, it is far better to get 25 or 30 per cent of something-or whatever the rate is-than 60 per cent of nothing.

This Budget is a disappointment for all Australians because 29 per cent of taxpayers will move into higher income tax brackets. Three-quarters of a million Australians will be pushed into higher tax brackets. Half a million of those three-quarters of a million people will move into the 46c in the dollar tax bracket and one-quarter of a million Australian men and women will move into the 60c in the dollar tax bracket. More and more people are finding less and less incentive to work harder, to achieve more, to be more productive and more prosperous and to create a more prosperous nation.

Occasionally it is appropriate to give credit where credit is due. Much has been said by the Treasurer and this Government about their doing wonders by reducing the size of the deficit. The average Australian working man or woman owes $8,400 to somebody else. The average Australian taxpayer contributes nearly $1,000 in his taxes to pay the interest bill on the moneys borrowed to fund the accumulated deficits of the past. The latest letter from the Syntec economic advisory group shows that Australia has the third highest current account deficit as a proportion of gross domestic product of any of the countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. Of course, that inspired the economic adviser, Professor Fred Gruen, to warn us that the International Monetary Fund may have to be called in to intervene in Australia's financial affairs. The financial debt of this Federal Government has reached a serious stage. It is alarming. We need to do something about it. We are mortgaging our nation's future. As a young Australian I do not want in 20 years time to pay taxes to pay for services and facilities that were provided by governments 20 years ago. We need to get on with the job of reducing the deficit and paying off some of the amounts owed by this Federal Government.

When talking of creating jobs, one cannot go past talking about the small businesses of Australia. Probably most of us know that small businesses represent the single largest employer in Australia. There are over 600,000 small businesses in this country.

We cannot talk about job creation and employment opportunities without very briefly mentioning the very high costs of production in this country. This Budget will not benefit Australia. This Budget will set Australia further and further behind the eight ball. We need a government which is prepared to bring down a Budget that creates increased productivity and prosperity. We need a government prepared to give us industrial laws and conditions that help to promote increased production. Unfortunately, we will not get all of those things under a Hawke socialist Government. Opposition members want to abolish the assets test, but they would abolish all telephone concessions for pensioners. The pensioners would not be happy about that. All veterans' affairs pensioners and age pensioners get a concession on telephones. That is very important, because if they are sick they must have a telephone in order to ring their doctor, and so on. There will be no Telecom to make a profit. That will have been sold off. In the second year there will be this continuing debt. It is the same with every service. If the Commonwealth Bank were sold, who would run the school banking service? Or would that be abandoned? The social security budget would have to fork out that money.

Another service that will go is directory assistance. This is the only country in which one can ring up directory assistance without charge. That is one matter that the honourable member for Wannon has forgotten. That will be the first thing to go-that service for all the farmers and the private sector people who ring up all the time. It cost $25m a year to run directory assistance. That will be abandoned immediately along with all the other services that Telecom provides, mainly in the country. It is a disgrace. It shows the debasing of the National Party members in this House when they can support something that will treble or quadruple the cost of telephones in the country, this philosophy of selling off anything that is making a profit. Those services that are making a profit are the only ones that they will sell.

It is absolute rubbish to talk about the notion that everyone who buys a share on 1 January 2080-when the Opposition eventually wins under the pendulum theory-is then locked into it, because such people can sell their shares, or, when they die, they cannot attach such draconian conditions to their next of kin. The honourable member for Wannon is talking absolute balderdash and rubbish. The electorate will see it as that, and the voters will never return Opposition members to the treasury bench.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am one of those people in this House who are very disappointed with the Budget. I am disappointed for all of Australia, but I am more disappointed for all of the farmers and people on the land in my electorate. The people about whom I am most concerned are the young farmers. These are farmers who have gone into debt in the past, people with initiative and a bit of get up and go in them, and people who have implemented innovative ideas to farm their land, particularly those irrigation farmers in the Riverina who have brought in laser levelling and other modern techniques to have a go at trying to produce some wealth for this country. Unfortunately, because of higher costs that have arisen, such as increases in fuel costs and in all types of taxes and charges--
—Interest rates.

—I was about to mention interest rates. They are the ultimate charge that is really destroying such people. A person in my office the other day was telling me something about interest rates. He said that people in the service industries can get rates as low as 14 per cent, but for people on the land rates start at 16 3/4 per cent and can be anything from there upwards. Some of these young farmers have gone into sheds or substandard accommodation on the block thinking that eventually they would get the block going and move into some reasonable accommodation for their families, but now, worse than having to stay in a tin shed for some years, it looks as though they will have to walk off the land, not only giving up all the land and every- thing they have put into it but also having to repay substantial debts.

SPEECH.PARA: The present situation is so bad that we must think about ways and means of providing rural finance to help such people. The Fraser- Anthony Government introduced drought relief subsidies, mainly to save the national herd and the national flock because if these had been allowed to deteriorate, it would have taken years and years to bring them up again to the numbers needed to provide some wealth for this country. The situation is reaching the point at which we will have to provide some sort of scheme to save the farmers, let alone the flocks.

In the recent Budget we had an allocation of $16.8m for the rural adjustment scheme. The other day I was on the road between Ivanhoe and Hay, and I was speaking to a farmer who had cattle in the long paddock. He told me that unless things improved and unless he got those cattle fattened and sold he would be down to the tune of $1.2m. I was talking to him about the rural adjustment scheme, and he said: `If you give me $1.2m out of that scheme, that does not leave much for all the other farmers of Australia'.

The rural community does not want special treatment or handouts, but it wants to survive. Unless the Government does something about interest rates, which it is keeping artificially high in order to attract money into the country to prop up the ailing dollar, and unless it does something drastic and very shortly, we will not have too many farmers left. This is not just a plea for the farmer. If the man on the land is not going well and if all the rural communities are not going well, the capital cities, as they will find out, will not be going too well either. The people on the land provide 46 per cent of our overseas earnings. If anything happens to them, the nation is in real trouble.

We had income equalisation deposits which helped people on the land at one stage, but this Government did away with that scheme. That scheme allowed such people to average out their earnings and pay less tax. It allowed money to go into the Primary Industry Bank of Australia, and in this way helped the man on the land. It appears now that with the loss of that scheme the Government will have to institute some other scheme if it wants these people to survive.

Meetings are taking place all over Australia in regard to the problems faced by the man on the land. A meeting is being organised at Jerilderie for Monday, 16 September. An invitation is extended to anyone who can get along to that meeting, at which there will be discussion of rural finance and the need to support the man on the land and people in rural communities, who are really small businessmen who need help if they are to survive. I am not asking the Government to assist; I am pleading with the Government to do something about interest rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —The new conservative movement in Australia, the Right or dry or whatever we now have to call the Opposition, sees the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation as only one of its targets in its opposition to the United Nations system. Because of the growing attacks on UNESCO I strongly support the recent call made by Dr Ken Wiltshire, Associate Professor of Government at the University of Queensland, for the establishment of a Friends of UNESCO organisation in Australia, along the lines of similar groups in the United States of America and the United Kingdom. There should be strenuous efforts to increase understanding of UNESCO.

SPEECH.PARA: The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation, was born out of the horror of World War II. UNESCO was a positive, rationalist response to the irrationalism that led to war. In 1946 the Organisation was established to foster peace by promoting international intellectual co-operation. `Since wars begin in the minds of men', runs the Organisation's constitution, `it is in the minds of men that the defences of peace must be constructed'. It is ironic then, in a year when memories of that war are being recalled at various ceremonies, and through television programs, that a heavy cloud hangs over UNESCO. At a time when the fortieth anniversary of the end of the war is being commemorated, the existence of UNESCO is being challenged. UNESCO's achievements have been forgotten. Criticism of the Organisation's management and some of its programs has created a climate in which the worth of such international machinery can be doubted, not only overseas but also in Australia. It seems that in the last 25 years awareness of UNESCO, along with the rest of the united Nations system, has declined greatly in Australia, particularly among young people. UNESCO has enormous potential for good. Perhaps more than any other United Nations body, its goals embody the ethical concerns of the founders of the United Nations system. Should UNESCO flounder, then the rest of the United Nations system will lose intellectual and moral strength.

One hundred and sixty nations belong to UNESCO and Australia was one of the earliest signatories. UNESCO is one of the largest international agencies. It differs from other United Nations agencies in that its activities relate to several broad issues-education, natural science, social science, culture and communication. The other agencies focus on one area-the World Health Organisation on health, the Food and Agriculture Organisation on food, the International Labour Organisation on labour, and so on. UNESCO is also different from the other agencies in the stress placed on intellectual activity. UNESCO is not simply an aid agency for Third World countries. This is not its essential function. It is primarily a source of seminal thinking on world problems that is of benefit to developed as well as developing countries.

UNESCO is a difficult organisation to run. The north-south and east-west dimensions of the Organisation perhaps give rise to greater debates than in other international agencies because UNESCO is seeking to make so many more intellectual judgments. It deals with a host of areas that are focal points for debate by people of different ideologies. For example, the question of whether the scope of human rights in international law should be extended beyond individuals to peoples, such as Australian Aboriginals, has created tension within UNESCO. Some have feared that the notion of people's rights will be a means for states to undermine individual human rights. However, turning away from such issues because they are politically contentious is not the answer. They are issues that must be addressed. It is necessary that they be recognised as politically important issues that need to be debated within a body with a brief such as UNESCO's. The task in future is to find a way in which people with different ideologies can deal with them.

International standards have been set in a host of areas through UNESCO. Standards are developed by the Organisation, and member States agree to adhere to the standards through the signing of conventions. Currently there are 30 UNESCO conventions ranging from universal copyright to the protection of important natural and cultural sites. In Australia we are most familiar with the UNESCO Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage. Countries which are signatories to the convention are required to do all they can to ensure the preservation of sites listed under it. The inclusion of the Western Tasmania wilderness national parks on the World Heritage List enabled the Federal Government to prevent a vast area of the parks from being flooded by the building of the Franklin Dam. As Australia was a signatory to the convention, the Federal Government was able to introduce legislation and undertake litigation to protect the area. More generally, the inclusion of Australian sites on the World Heritage List has helped to raise awareness of the importance of preserving the environment in this country. The World Heritage Convention illustrates how Australia profits nationally by membership of UNESCO. Australia's participation in UNESCO should not be seen as one-way traffic of Australian money and expertise.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to broach a topic tonight which will be of interest to honourable members from Tasmania, to members of the National Party of Australia and to honourable members who have electorates on the outskirts of Melbourne. I shall talk about bushfire research. Fires like the famous 1939 Black Friday fires in Victoria, fires in January this year around Maryborough and particularly the fires on Ash Wednesday 1983 in Victoria are the fires I wish to have honourable members in this House recall. The Ash Wednesday fire alone cost the community dearly. It cost it dearly in lives. Some 50 lives or so were lost. I understand that it has been estimated that property losses in that fire were around $500m to $600m.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the report by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation, tabled in October last year, which was entitled `Bushfires in the Australian Environment'. We are indebted to the Chairman of that Committee, the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton). I was once Chairman of that Committee. I think, Mr Speaker, that you too were a member of that Committee. The Committee has released many excellent reports. It is a shame that with all the hard work that committees do, very often the recommendations and the reports are pigeonholed. Let us make sure that this Milton report and its recommendations are not so pigeonholed and forgotten. The Milton report pointed out the need for research to bring about greater understanding of bushfires and to lead to methods for their prevention. The report pointed out that a witness to the inquiry said that if we were able to spend nationally a sum of $800,000 a year we might be able to save 50 per cent of the lives that are currently lost in bushfires and some 80 per cent of the loss of buildings and other properties.

The Milton report went on to suggest that we should have an annual expenditure of $1m on research into bushfires. Some research has been carried on from time to time. We have reached the stage now where the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, on the recommendations of the Milton report, has decided to establish a national bushfire research unit. It will be established in Canberra in the Division of Forestry, with another section in the Division of Atmospherics in Melbourne. Unfortunately, the unit will have only a very small budget of some $400,000. The sum of $300,000 has been released as a result of the conclusion of Project Aquarius. Another $100,000 injection has been allocated thanks to the foresight of the Minister for Science (Mr Jones) which brings the amount up to $400,000. This is still only one-seventh of one per cent of the total CSIRO budget. It is a piddling amount to be allocated for the needs of bushfire research. It certainly does not measure up to the $1m that was recommended.

I turn to another recommendation which I think should be taken up immediately by State and Federal Ministers responsible for bushfire prevention-the establishment of a national bushfire research fund. Such a fund could carry out research which the CSIRO cannot. Instead of concentrating on scientific and ecological research, it could also look into sociological research. It could examine what happens in evacuations. It could examine post-fire trauma, and so on. It could look into what sort of gardens should be planted and what are the more fire retardant species that should be grown around houses. If the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Cabinet were to decide that tax deductibility should be extended to donations to such a fund from businesses and private sources, we could build up a reasonable amount of research funds which could be directed into areas which the CSIRO cannot tackle. In the past, we have had research into flood mitigation and research on animal diseases that threaten the livestock of our primary industries. It is about time that we looked into the devastation caused by bushfires and looked towards having a national bushfire research fund.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly tonight about the situation in South Africa and a particular suggestion I have for the Australian Government to change, if not radically, at least marginally, its approach to that situation. In my view, the current Australian debate on South Africa is a little sterile. We should be looking at constructive ways to encourage reform in South Africa and not just make rhetorical denunciations of what is happening there, abhorrent as it may be. One of the ways that we can do that is through our link with the Commonwealth of Nations. As I understand it so far, this is not an avenue that has been explored by the Government. One idea that I wish to promote this evening is that the Australian Government should go to the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in the Bahamas in October and ensure that South Africa is high on the agenda. This should be done in a constructive and not a destructive way.

SPEECH.PARA: Most honourable members in this House are deeply concerned about instability in South Africa. There are four basic reasons for that concern. Firstly, it almost goes without saying that every member of this House would regard apartheid as morally unacceptable. I pass over that point quickly but, of course, it is a point which is fundamental. Secondly, in my view, the situation in South Africa does have a very important bearing on global stability. We in Australia have as much right to be concerned about global stability that affects us as does any other nation, even if that global stability is affected by an unstable internal situation in another country. For example, we are concerned about internal situations in the Lebanon and Israel, but particularly the Lebanon, because of the impact they will have on global stability. Thirdly, we are concerned about South Africa because we appreciate that all developing countries see South Africa as a last major outpost of colonialism, with all the implications that has for white superiority over blacks, something which, naturally, they regard, and I would hope we all regard, as completely abhorrent. I believe that our commitment to self-determination of all peoples and to the quality of opportunities should be axiomatic.

Fourthly-this is the point I wish to make tonight in relation to the Commonwealth-the black community proponents of democratic and peaceful reform in South Africa will be overwhelmed by the advocates of violent and radical solutions if the Afrikaner whites do not choose a path to reform and do not do so very soon. That is why, in a practical sense, it is in our interest to encourage reform in that country. The black community in South Africa will inevitably follow the leaders in that country who can deliver. Those who cannot will quickly be abandoned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Release Mandela.

—Recent gallup polls have pointed out the tenuous nature of the situation there. Having said that, there is a possibility for some sort of stable and constructive solution. After all, 80 per cent of blacks in South Africa apparently believe in multiracial government. However, nearly half of them believe that violence can be justified. I think that bears out how little time there is left for a constructive solution to be found. I believe that the Commonwealth should be able to take constructive action by drawing up at the CHOGM meeting in the Bahamas an agenda for reform. It should draw up an agenda which is broad enough to enable the South Africans to develop their own solutions to their problems and which recognises that reforms cannot be achieved overnight.

SPEECH.PARA: The basic item that the agenda must address is the commencement of constructive negotiations between all races towards a system of government which represents all South Africans and guarantees their rights and the properties of minorities. They need equal opportunity in the economic and social field. As one honourable member interjected, moves have to be made towards the release of political detainees and prisoners such as Nelson Mandela. Those are the items that I believe should be on the Commonwealth agenda for reform. If that agenda is not met all will be lost. There will be a steady march towards extremism in South Africa and extremist solutions which will lead to gross instability.
